title: Resilient Control Design for EV Fast Charging Unit Consisting of Multiple SAB Converter Modules
authors: Apostolos S. Manasis, Panos C. Papageorgiou, George C. Konstantopoulos, Antonio T. Alexandridis
abstract: An electric vehicle (EV) fast charging unit usually consists of multiple modules connected in parallel to share the total current among them and achieve high power ratings. In this article, a charging unit with multiple parallel single active bridge (SAB) converter modules is considered and a novel nonlinear resilient controller (NLRC) is proposed to achieve all of the following properties: 1) accurate current sharing among multiple SAB modules during normal operation; 2) inherently limit the instantaneous current of each module within a given range at all times; 3) rigorously guarantee closed-loop system stability; and 4) enhance the charging unit resilience under abnormal operation (e.g., module set-point attack and sensor/measurement fault). Using nonlinear analysis and invariant set theory, the boundedness of the instantaneous current for each SAB module is rigorously proved. Furthermore, closed-loop system stability is analytically shown based on matrix properties independently of the charging unit or controller parameters, opposed to conventional root-locus analysis that relies on a specific set of system parameters. Moreover, the resilience property of the novel NLRC is analytically articulated in the case where one or more modules are compromised due to set-point attack or sensor/communication failures. The effectiveness of the proposed controller is demonstrated against the state-of-the-art control structures using both simulation and a suitable experimental testbed for both normal and abnormal scenarios, including an experimental implementation of an entire charging session (typical EV battery charging curve).

title: Discriminant Analysis of Organizational and Personal Factors Affecting Employee Well-Being in the Hospitality Industry
authors: Helen T. Cabije
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: This study examines the relationship between dimensions of work culture and the well-being of hotel employees using discriminant analysis. Data were collected through a structured questionnaire distributed across various departments and job levels, measuring key constructs including job satisfaction (JS), subjective well-being (SWB), social support (SS), supportive practices (SP), and motivation (M), with validated instruments ensuring data reliability. Unlike most hospitality research, which often relies on correlation or regression-based methods, this study introduces discriminant analysis as a predictive classification approach, addressing a methodological gap in employee well-being research. The discriminant model classified employees into distinct psychological and organizational profiles, with the first two discriminant functions explaining 93.33% of the total variance. Results confirmed that both organizational culture factors (such as SP and SS) and personal factors (such as motivation and well-being) significantly differentiate employee groups. These findings underscore the importance of fostering a supportive work environment and implementing policies that improve both job satisfaction and psychological health. For hospitality managers and HR professionals, the results provide actionable insights to improve employee engagement, reduce burnout, and ultimately improve service quality in the industry.

title: Multi Channel Fusion Framework for Tomato Leaf Disease Classification Using Modified Cnn Backbones and Preprocessing Aware Input Design
authors: Rudi Limantara, Elizabeth Nathania Witanto, Christopher Andreas, Satria Adi Nugraha, Adi Suryaputra Paramita, Christopher Andreas
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: This research develops a deep learning system for identifying tomato leaf diseases by combining multiple image processing techniques with advanced neural networks. The approach takes input images and creates three different versions: the original RGB photo, a segmentation mask that isolates just the leaf area, and contrast-enhanced version made using Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE). These three image types get merged together and fed into modified versions of established CNN models - ResNet50, EfficientNetB0, and MobileNetV2. The models also use data augmentation with various geometric and lighting changes to help them work better on new images. Results show that using this combined input approach boosts classification performance across all the neural network models, with EfficientNetB0 reaching the best F 1 -score of 0.999. The leaf segmentation part, done with U-Net and U-Net using FP32 precision, accurately separates leaves from backgrounds with Dice scores over 0.98. The complete system handles real-world challenges well, including different surface textures, lighting conditions, and leaf orientations that farmers encounter in the field. The main contribution here is bringing together semantic understanding, structural information, and visual details in one classification system, creating a practical tool for automated disease detection in modern farming. Future work could focus on making this run on mobile devices and adding AI explanation features so farmers can understand and trust the system's decisions better.

title: LASFNet: A Lightweight Attention-Guided Self-Modulation Feature Fusion Network for Multimodal Object Detection
authors: Lei Hao, Lina Xu, Chang Liu, Yanni Dong
abstract: Effective deep feature extraction via feature-level fusion is crucial for multimodal object detection. However, previous studies often involve complex training processes that integrate modality-specific features by stacking multiple feature-level fusion units, leading to significant computational overhead. To address this issue, we propose a lightweight attention-guided self-modulation feature fusion network (LASFNet). The LASFNet adopts a single feature-level fusion unit to enable high-performance detection, thereby simplifying the training process. The attention-guided self-modulation feature fusion (ASFF) module in the model adaptively adjusts the responses of fused features at both global and local levels, promoting comprehensive and enriched feature generation. Additionally, a lightweight feature attention transformation module (FATM) is designed at the neck of LASFNet to enhance the focus on fused features and minimize information loss. Extensive experiments on three representative datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves a favorable efficiency–accuracy tradeoff. Compared to state-of-the-art methods, LASFNet reduced the number of parameters and computational cost by as much as 90% and 85%, respectively, while improving detection accuracy mean average precision (mAP) by 1%–3%. The code will be open-sourced at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/leileilei2000/LASFNet</uri>

title: Evaluating NB-IoT and Sigfox for Energy-Efficient Data Loggers in Sewer Infrastructure
authors: M. Martínez-Peiró, R. Torres-Curado, J. Gomis-Tena
abstract: This work presents the design and evaluation of a low-power data logger for multi-sensor data acquisition, intended for deployment in urban sewage infrastructure. The system integrates IoT communication capabilities to interface with a smart city’s centralized data platform. Two LPWA (Low Power Wide Area) communication technologies-Narrowband IoT (NBIoT) and Sigfox/LoRa-are analyzed and compared in terms of power consumption, hardware cost, and data transmission performance. The results offer practical guidance for selecting the most suitable communication protocol based on application-specific constraints, such as message frequency, energy availability, and bidirectional communication requirements. Sigfox is selected for occasional alert messages, while NB-IoT is used for the daily bulk transmission of measurements.

title: RF-3DGS: Wireless Channel Modeling With Radio Radiance Field and 3D Gaussian Splatting
authors: Lihao Zhang, Haijian Sun, Samuel Berweger, Camillo Gentile, Rose Qingyang Hu
abstract: Precisely modeling radio propagation in complex environments has been a significant challenge, especially with the advent of 5G and beyond networks, where managing massive antenna arrays demands more detailed information. Traditional methods, such as empirical models and ray tracing, often fall short, either due to insufficient details or because of challenges for real-time applications. Inspired by the newly proposed 3D Gaussian Splatting method in the computer vision domain, which outperforms other methods in reconstructing optical radiance fields, we propose RF-3DGS, a novel approach that enables precise site-specific reconstruction of radio radiance fields from sparse samples. RF-3DGS offers high efficiency, requiring only a few minutes for training and achieving fast inference for any arbitrary receiver pose within milliseconds. Furthermore, RF-3DGS can provide fine-grained Spatial Channel State Information (Spatial-CSI) of these paths, including the channel gain, the delay, the angle of arrival (AoA), and the angle of departure (AoD). Our experiments, calibrated through real-world measurements, demonstrate that RF-3DGS not only significantly improves reconstruction quality, training efficiency, and rendering speed compared to state-of-the-art methods, but also holds great potential for supporting wireless communication and advanced applications such as Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC). Code and dataset are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/SunLab-UGA/RF-3DGS</uri>

title: Real-Time Radar Pulse Parameter Extraction on FPGA Platforms
authors: Jesús Grajal, Carlos García-de-la-Cueva, Daniel Fortún Sánchez, Marisa López-Vallejo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In modern combat scenarios, the increasing number of radars operating in the same coverage area complicates spectrum monitoring tasks and imposes critical latency requirements on electronic warfare systems. This paper presents a real-time FPGA implementation of a pulse parameter extractor (PPE) for pulsed radar signals. The PPE provides information on each pulse, including the time of arrival, pulse width, carrier frequency and the phase difference between coherent receivers. The quality of these estimates is determined by the signal-to-noise ratio. The implementation of these algorithms on FPGA platforms are based on low-complexity pipelined processing schemes, with a latency between <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.25\ \mu s$</tex-math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.65\ \mu s$</tex-math></inline-formula> and a maximum clock frequency of 275 MHz. This latency makes the approach suitable for operation in highly dense electromagnetic domains.

title: Sensor Placement Strategies for 3-D AOA Localization under General Convex Deployment Constraints
authors: Pan Li, Jianfeng Li, Mingyi You, Jianghao Xiao, Qihui Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The sensor-target geometry has a significant impact on localization performance. Existing sensor placement strategies for three-dimensional (3-D) angle-of-arrival (AOA) localization have not accounted for general convex deployment constraints. This paper extends and improves a recently proposed block majorization-minimization (block-MM) method for 3-D AOA sensor placement, making it capable of handling general convex deployment constraints for AOA sensors. Specifically, we formulate the problem based on the A-optimality criterion, and each sensor's position is subject to the constraint of lying within a pre-defined deployment constraint set. We derive a quadratic surrogate function for the formulated problem. The method guarantees a successive reduction in the objective function value until convergence. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively find an appropriate sensor-target geometry that enhances performance.

title: Robust Image Semantic Communication via Wavelet-Attentive JSCC Under Adversarial and Channel Perturbations
authors: Zhen Huang, Yunjian Jia, Wanli Wen, Qingqing Li, Liang Liang, Xinyue Liu
abstract: Semantic communication receives significant attention for its ability to efficiently transmit meaningful information rather than pursuing bit-level accuracy, thereby minimizing resource consumption. However, in addition to wireless channel interference, this paradigm is vulnerable to semantic impairments caused by adversarial attacks. Recent advances in deep learning-based Joint Source-Channel Coding (JSCC) significantly improve communication robustness against physical channel noise but often overlook semantic-level perturbations. In this paper, we propose a wavelet transform frequency-domain attention feature (WTAF) module, which employs multilevel wavelet decomposition to effectively separate semantic structures from high-frequency adversarial noise. It also incorporates a channel-aware attention mechanism that dynamically adapts semantic feature extraction based on real-time channel conditions. We integrate WTAF to design a JSCC model for robust image semantic communication under adversarial interference and wireless channel interference conditions. Simulation results show that the proposed JSCC scheme outperforms existing JSCC models and traditional separate source-channel coding in terms of reconstruction quality, semantic integrity, and overall robustness, particularly under severe semantic degradation.

title: A Hybrid LBM-FVM Solver for Simulating Multiphase Multi-Component Fluids_supp2-3644004.mp4
authors: Xiaopei Liu
abstract: Multiphase and multi-component fluid flows are highly intricate, exhibiting dynamic behaviors that challenge conventional simulation methods, especially across a wide range of operating conditions. Adding fluid-solid interactions further escalates this complexity, requiring simulations that are both physically accurate and computationally more tractable. Existing methods often fall short in aspects of either accuracy, efficiency, or stability, and sometimes may also consume excessive memory, rendering them unsuitable for many practical applications. In this paper, we introduce a novel, more practical solution combining a collision-enhanced lattice Boltzmann method with a finite-volume approach. This hybrid solver is designed to effectively simulate multiphase, multi-component flows via the phase-field modeling with a novel wetting boundary treatment in the finite-volume framework, while significantly reducing memory consumption. It enables simulations of multiple fluid phases under varied conditions, capturing rich interfacial behaviors. Additionally, it incorporates an immersed-boundary method to efficiently handle complex fluid-solid interactions. Validation tests confirm that our method produces physically consistent results and demonstrates accuracy across multiple evaluations. We provide comprehensive simulation results, along with comparisons of memory consumption and efficiency, highlighting the practical utility and superiority of our solver over conventional methods.

title: Characterizing the Dynamic Hosting Capacity of Distribution Networks Integrated with Distributed GAI Data Center
authors: Ruixuan Qiu, Tiance Zhang, Gengyin Li, Ming Zhou, Qinyong Zhou, Jianxiao Wang
abstract: The widespread deployment of distributed Large Language Model (LLM) data centers across communities exposes distribution networks to significant stochastic power fluctuations driven by Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI) training and inference tasks. Such random workload variations risk exceeding hosting capacity limits of Distribution Network (DN), while capacity expansion of critical equipment (e.g., transformers) to accommodate such volatility remains economically unjustifiable. To bridge this gap, the concept of Dynamic Hosting Capacity (DHC), enabling spatiotemporal characterization of distribution network constraints to optimize GAI data center integration. Detailed phase-specific power consumption models are established for LLM data centers, systematically quantifying their multidimensional spatiotemporal impact on DN safety margins through high-dimensional feasible region analysis. Furthermore, an efficient DHC characterization method based on the projection equivalence theory is introduced, which maps the high-dimensional feasible region onto the node-level dynamic hosting capacity indicators of the GAI interconnection nodes. Case studies based on a modified IEEE 33-bus feeder validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Order-Aware Deep Learning for Drug Combination Benefit Prediction in Cancer Cell Lines
authors: Xuan Liu, Jian Zhang, Jie Yang, Shichao Liu, Wen Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Drug combination therapy has exhibited favorable effects in treating cancer patients, with less toxicity and adverse reactions compared to monotherapy. To accelerate the discovery of therapeutic drug combinations, numerous computational methods have been developed to predict drug synergy in cancer cell lines, typically modeling the task as binary classification (synergistic vs non-synergistic) or regression (continuous synergy scores). Yet, a recent study proposes categorizing drug combination benefits into multiple ordered classes (e.g., synergy, bliss additivity, independent actions) based on clinical activities, and suggests that drug combinations remain valuable if they reduce cancer cell viability, even without defined synergy. To distinguish various levels of combination benefits, we present a novel order-aware deep learning model, called OrderCombo. Specifically, OrderCombo extracts the drug representation via a pretrained chemical language model and the cell line representation via an omics-oriented linear network. Then, these representations are fused into a unified embedding for each drug-drug-cell line triplet, by leveraging a hybrid encoder that combines concatenation-based dependencies and attention-based interactions. Finally, an ordinal contrastive loss is designed to promote a discriminative embedding space and maintain class ordinality, thereby improving the predictions of drug combination benefits. We evaluate OrderCombo on a large-scale combination benefit dataset, and in silico results show that our method outperforms the state-of-the-art baselines in terms of prediction accuracy, while maintaining robust generalization to unseen drug pairs and cell lines. Substantial case studies further demonstrate OrderCombo's potential value in discovering novel anticancer drug combinations across different therapeutic levels.

title: Outliers Adaptation Exploration and Centroids Matching Label Refinement for Unsupervised Person Re-identification
authors: Longfei Li, Qing Han, Weidong Min, Qi Wang, Meng Zhu, Zheng Huang, Ziyang Deng, Ruibin Chen
abstract: Existing unsupervised person re-identification (Re-ID) methods obtain pseudo-labels mainly by clustering to optimize the model. Most methods only use clustered instances to provide supervised information for model training without considering the possible value information of un-clustered outliers. Some methods use un-clustered outliers for training and show promising results, but their strategies for using un-clustered outliers are limited in applicability. Furthermore, unsatisfactory feature embedding and imperfect clustering cannot guarantee that instances within clusters have the same identity, resulting in generated pseudo-labels containing noise. To solve the above problems, outliers adaptation exploration (OAE) and centroids matching label refinement (CMLR) are proposed in this paper. First, OAE is designed to explore the value information of un-clustered outliers. OAE implements the nearest clustered instance neighborhood constraint and the maximum centroid distance constraint on the un-clustered outliers based on the feature distribution to update the clusters, thereby achieving a healthy balance between the number of training samples and model accuracy. Second, CMLR is proposed to alleviate the inherent noise in pseudo-labels. CMLR considers the similarity relationship between clustered instances and clusters in accordance with the cluster distribution to refine pseudo-labels, prompting features to learn from probability distributions with cluster distribution similarity relationship information. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, which outperforms the state-of-the-art performance in unsupervised learning and unsupervised domain adaptation settings.

title: Grid Frequency Stability Support Potential of Data Center: A Quantitative Assessment of Flexibility
authors: Pengyu Ren, Wei Sun, Yifan Wang, Gareth Harrison
abstract: The rapid expansion of data center infrastructure is reshaping power system dynamics by significantly increasing electricity demand while also offering potential for fast and controllable flexibility. To ensure reliable operation under such conditions, the frequency-secured unit commitment (Safe UC) problem must be solved with enhanced modeling of demand-side frequency response. In this work, we propose a data-driven linearization framework based on decision tree–based constraint learning (DT-CL) to embed nonlinear nadir frequency constraints into mixed- integer linear programming (MILP). This approach enables tractable co-optimization of generation schedules and fast frequency response (FFR) from data centers. Through case studies on both a benchmark system and a 2030 future scenario with higher DC penetration, we demonstrate that increasing the proportion of flexible DC load consistently improves system cost efficiency and supports renewable integration. However, this benefit exhibits diminishing marginal returns, motivating the introduction of the Marginal Flexibility Value (MFV) metric to quantify the economic value of additional flexibility. The results highlight that as DCs become a larger share of system load, their active participation in frequency response will be increasingly indispensable for maintaining both economic and secure system operations.

title: Survey of AI-enabled IoT for Wildfire Prediction, Detection, and Post-Operations
authors: Aly Badary, DongPing Chen, Sai Wang, Weiwei Li, Siqi Chen, Cuiting Huang, Michal Aibin
abstract: Wildfires are destructive natural disasters that pose severe risks to ecological systems and human lives. This survey explores the integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies, collectively known as AIoT, in the management of wildfires across three critical phases: prediction, detection, and post-operations. By leveraging real-time data collection, robust communication protocols, and advanced machine learning (ML) models, AIoT systems address the complex challenges associated with wildfire management. We examine AIoT applications across these phases: prediction, where traditional machine-learning and fuzzy-logic methods have evolved into deep-learning approaches; detection, which combines advanced sensors and communication networks with real-time algorithms; and post-operations, covering damage assessment, vegetation recovery, and ecosystem restoration. We present an integrated operational framework showing how these traditionally isolated phases could function as interconnected components with automated data pipelines and feedback mechanisms. The survey identifies seven critical challenges—including hardware constraints, false alarm rates, and network reliability—along with eight future research directions aimed at advancing the field toward practical, scalable deployment.

title: From Edge to Edge: A Flow-Inspired Scheduling Planner for Multi-Robot Systems
authors: Han Liu, Yu Jin, Mingyue Cui, Boyang Li, Tianjiang Hu, Kai Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Trajectory planning is crucial in multi-robot systems, particularly in environments with numerous obstacles. While extensive research has been conducted in this field, the challenge of coordinating multiple robots to flow collectively from one side of the map to the other—such as in crossing missions through obstacle-rich spaces—has received limited attention. This paper focuses on this directional traversal scenario by introducing a real-time scheduling scheme that enables multi-robot systems to move from edge to edge, emulating the smooth and efficient flow of water. Inspired by network flow optimization, our scheme decomposes the environment into a flow-based network structure, enabling the efficient allocation of robots to paths based on real-time congestion levels. The proposed scheduling planner operates on top of existing collision avoidance algorithms, aiming to minimize overall traversal time by balancing detours and waiting times. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme in achieving fast and coordinated traversal. Furthermore, real-world flight tests with ten drones validate its practical feasibility. This work contributes a flow-inspired, real-time scheduling planner tailored for directional multi-robot traversal in complex, obstacle-rich environments. Code: https://github.com/chengji253/FlowPlanner.

title: Weather-Driven Machine Learning Approach for Predicting Rice Production in East Java
authors: James Dillon Wongso, Hans Robert Gunawan, Ivan Sebastian Edbert
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: This research develops a machine learning-based prediction model that uses weather variables for predicting rice production in East Java, Indonesia's largest rice-producing province. The increasing variability in climatic patterns requires precise prediction models to support planning and improve food security. This study employed four machine learning models, including Random Forest, Support Vector Regressor, Multiple Linear Regression, and Decision Tree, trained and evaluated on 15 years of weather and rice production data spanning 2010-2024. The models went through comprehensive data preprocessing stages that involved outlier detection, temporal aggregation (converting daily weather observations to annual data points), standardization, and feature selection based on correlation analysis. Hyperparameter tuning was conducted using GridSearchCV on all four models. The Random Forest model achieved the most consistent performance across all evaluation metrics, with the Mean Absolute Percentage Error of 16.53% and Root Mean Square Error of 58751.71. This research highlights the effectiveness of machine learning while utilizing weather variables to predict rice production in East Java.

title: Like Human Rethinking: Contour Transformer AutoRegression for Referring Remote Sensing Interpretation
authors: Jinming Chai, Licheng Jiao, Xiaoqiang Lu, Lingling Li, Fang Liu, Long Sun, Xu Liu, Wenping Ma, Weibin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Referring remote sensing interpretation holds significant application value in various scenarios such as ecological protection, resource exploration, and emergency management. However, referring remote sensing expression comprehension and segmentation (RRSECS) faces critical challenges, including micro-target localization drift problem caused by insufficient extraction of boundary features in existing paradigms. Moreover, when transferred to remote sensing domains, polygon-based methods encounter issues such as contour-boundary misalignment and multi-task co-optimization conflicts problems. In this paper, we propose SeeFormer, a novel contour autoregressive paradigm specifically designed for RRSECS, which accurately locates and segments micro, irregular targets in remote sensing imagery. We first introduce a brain-inspired feature refocus learning (BIFRL) module that progressively attends to effective object features via a coarse-to-fine scheme, significantly boosting small-object localization and segmentation. Next, we present a language-contour enhancer (LCE) that injects shape-aware contour priors, and a corner-based contour sampler (CBCS) to improve mask-polygon reconstruction fidelity. Finally, we develop an autoregressive dual-decoder paradigm (ARDDP) that preserves sequence consistency while alleviating multi-task optimization conflicts. Extensive experiments on RefDIOR, RRSIS-D, and OPT-RSVG datasets under varying scenarios, scales, and task paradigms demonstrate transformative performance gains: compared to the baseline PolyFormer, our proposed SeeFormer improves oIoU and mIoU by 27.58% and 39.37% for referring image segmentation and by 18.94% and 28.90% for visual grounding on the RefDIOR dataset. The code will be publicly accessible at https://github.com/IPIU-XDU/RSFM.

title: Clustering of Regencies/Cities in Java Island Based on Decent Housing Indicators in 2024 Using K-Medoids and DBSCAN
authors: Linggar Putri Apririani, Tatik Widiharih, Fariz Budi Arafat
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: One of the indicators of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) related to sustainable cities and human settlements is the percentage of households with adequate housing. According to the Badan Pusat Statistik, several provinces in Indonesia, including three on the island of Java, namely DKI Jakarta, West Java, and Banten, still do not meet the criteria for adequate housing. An approach to analyze the disparity in the percentage of adequate housing on the island of Java can be carried out by clustering regencies/municipalities based on the 2024 adequate housing indicators to identify regions that have not yet met housing adequacy targets. This study uses the K-Medoids clustering algorithm and the Density-Based Spatial Clustering Algorithm with Noise (DBSCAN) because they are more robust against outliers and use Euclidean distance calculations. The K-medoids algorithm groups objects based on the shortest distance to the medoids as the cluster centers. The DBSCAN algorithm groups objects based on the density within a given area. The clustering results were validated using the Silhouette Index. A higher Silhouette Index value indicates better clustering performance. Based on the research, the K-Medoids algorithm formed an optimal number of two clusters with a Silhouette Index validation score of 0.5169, while the DBSCAN algorithm formed two optimal clusters and 29 noise points with a Silhouette Index validation score of 0.5853. The best clustering for regencies/municipalities on the island of Java, based on the 2024 adequate housing indicator, is two clusters and 29 noise points using the DBSCAN algorithm. The results may serve as a reference for the government to determine infrastructure and housing development priorities for lagging regions to achieve the SDGs.

title: Extending the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) in Mobile Language Learning: The Role of Information Quality and Autonomy
authors: Adrian A.D. Kristiawan, Hadyan Kholish Prasetio, Aulia R. Satria, Ragil Saputra, Dinar Mutiara Kusumo Nugraheni, Teotino Gomes Soares
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: This study extends the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) by incorporating Information Quality (IQ) from the Information System Success model and Autonomy (AUTO) from Self-Determination Theory, offering a more holistic framework that combines technical and motivational factors. While prior TAM-based research on mobile learning largely emphasized perceived usefulness (PU) and perceived ease of use (PEOU), the joint influence of IQ and autonomy has received limited attention. Using PLS-SEM on survey data from 138 users of mobile language learning applications, the results show that IQ and PEOU significantly predict PU, while PU and autonomy strongly influence behavioral intention to use (BIU). BIU, in turn, robustly predicts actual system use (AU). The extended model explains <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 1 \%}$</tex> of BIU and 52% of AU variance, demonstrating its explanatory strength. Theoretically, the findings advance TAM by integrating informational and motivational dimensions. Practically, they suggest that developers should emphasize high-quality content, tangible learning benefits, and features that enhance learner autonomy to promote adoption and sustained engagement. Limitations include a young sample and self-reported data; future research should test the model across diverse demographics and contexts.

title: IBKA-CEEMDAN-SPMF Algorithm for Denoising Electromagnetic Radiation in Loaded Coal-Rock
authors: Li Xin, Zhang Qiaochu, Yang Zhen, Zhou Jing, Li Hao, Han Lei, Zhao Yuanpeng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The electromagnetic signals generated during the coal rock loading process are prone to interference from environmental noise, making direct analysis difficult. To effectively extract the electromagnetic radiation characteristics during the fracture process, this paper proposes a modal component optimization method based on the multi-strategy improved black-wing kite algorithm (IBKA), the smooth-peak feature fusion classification (SPMF), and combines wavelet adaptive threshold denoising and CEEMDAN decomposition to construct the IBKA-CEEMDAN-SPMF joint denoising framework. By superimposing the spindle-shaped oscillation wave-form and the trend term to construct the simulated signal, the performance of each stage of the algorithm was systematically simulated and verified through single-axis loading experiments. The results show that the improved IBKA increases the convergence speed of CEEMDAN decomposition by 15% and improves the accuracy by 8.3%; the SPMF classification method can achieve more stable and reliable signal reconstruction; compared with other methods, the signal-to-noise ratio is improved by 13 dB. IBKA-CEEMDAN-SPMF shows excellent denoising ability in both simulated and measured signals, and the noise ratio of the denoised signal is the lowest at 0.0928, with the maximum noise ratio reduction of 53.9% compared to other comparison methods. The research proves that this method can be embedded in the precursory recognition models of time-domain, frequency-domain and mixed signals, providing effective technical support for the multi-source information fusion of coal rock dynamic disaster monitoring.

title: Unveiling Consumer Behaviour Insights via KMeans Customer Segmentation
authors: Alfonso Clement Sutantio, Yulian Indah Safitri, Daffa Fairuz Annizari, Sandy Kurniawan, Adhe Setya Pramayoga
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: The rapid growth of the global marketplace has compelled companies worldwide to swiftly formulate effective strategies to remain competitive. Customer segmentation emerges as an effective approach to assist business owners in tailoring strategies based on distinct groups. In this study, we conducted a comparative analysis of several clustering algorithms including K-Means, DBSCAN, Hierarchical Clustering, and Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM) on global consumer behaviour dataset. K-Means was identified as the optimal algorithm based on superior performance across key metrics (Silhouette Score, Davies-Bouldin Index, and CalinskiHarabasz Index). Using the elbow method, the optimal number of clusters was determined to be <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K=6$</tex>. The analysis revealed several insightful patterns: for example, Cluster 4 records the highest average spending ($404.28) with frequent purchases, while Cluster 2 demonstrates the highest brand loyalty at 90 % despite moderate spending. These findings provide both analytical insights and strategic business recommendations, offering a data-driven foundation for companies to improve targeting accuracy, strengthen customer loyalty, and maximize long-term value.

title: Development of an IoT-Based Wearable Device for Real-Time Posture Monitoring and Correction
authors: Jason Amanda Henrico Gonidjaja, Kadek Artika Chintya Meliana, Meiliana, Kenny Jingga
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Poor posture is a problem experienced by almost everyone in modern society, especially those who spend long hours sitting for studying or working. This can lead to musculoskeletal disorders and decreased productivity. This research aims to develop an Internet of Things (IoT)-based wearable device for posture detection and correction using an MPU6050 sensor, an ESP8266 microcontroller, and a vibration motor as feedback to the user. This device measures the user's body tilt angle in real-time and sends the data to the Blynk application and website, providing alerts when the posture is poor. Experimental results show that this system effectively monitors body posture and provides timely notifications with an average time of 1.172 milliseconds, hoping to help users develop healthier sitting habits. Experimental results reviewed in terms of user comfort indicate that the device still needs to be developed, as it only scored 2.5 out of 5. For further research, this system can be improved by integrating a database to store the user's posture history and incorporating advanced analytics for personalized feedback.

title: A Comparative Study of Machine Learning Models for Identification of Antiviral Peptides Using Various Encoded Features_supp1-3654071.pdf
authors: Mohammad Ali Moni
abstract: Viruses are a significant threat to human life, as demonstrated by the global COVID-19 pandemic and the Ebola outbreak. Diseases such as smallpox, AIDS, hepatitis, liver cancer, and cervical cancer often caused by the Human Papillomavirus can lead to fatal outcomes. Over the years, extensive research has focused on developing vaccines and antiviral drugs, which have successfully contained and, in some cases, eradicated viral infections. Recently, computational techniques, particularly machine learning algorithms, have made notable progress in identifying potential Antiviral Peptides (AVPs), thereby accelerating experimental validation for therapeutic applications. This study introduces machine learning techniques and a Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM) model combined with three feature-encoding methods to predict whether a protein sequence contains effective antiviral peptides. Eight machine learning algorithms were evaluated using both single-feature and combined feature encodings. Among them, the lightweight LGBM model trained on combined encoded features achieved the best performance, with an accuracy of 98%, precision of 97%, recall of 98%, F1-score of 98%, and an AUC of 1.00. Compared to existing models, the proposed approach achieved approximately 2% higher accuracy using individual encoding methods and about 3% higher accuracy with combined features. The reliability and effectiveness of the proposed model highlight its potential value for pharmaceutical development and academic research.

title: Vision Enhancing LLMs: Empowering Multimodal Knowledge Storage and Sharing in LLMs
authors: Yunxin Li, Zhenyu Liu, Baotian Hu, Wei Wang, Yuxin Ding, Xiaochun Cao, Min Zhang
abstract: Recent advancements in multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have achieved significant multimodal generation capabilities, akin to GPT-4. These models predominantly map visual information into language representation space, leveraging the vast knowledge and powerful text generation abilities of LLMs to produce multimodal instruction-following responses. We could term this method as LLMs for Vision because of its employing LLMs for visual understanding and reasoning, yet observe that these MLLMs neglect the potential of harnessing visual knowledge to enhance the overall capabilities of LLMs, which could be regarded as Vision Enhancing LLMs. In this paper, we propose an approach called MKS2, aimed at enhancing LLMs through empowering Multimodal Knowledge Storage and Sharing in LLMs. Specifically, we introduce Modular Visual Memory (MVM), a component integrated into the internal blocks of LLMs, designed to store open-world visual information efficiently. Additionally, we present a soft Mixture of Multimodal Experts (MoMEs) architecture in LLMs to invoke multimodal knowledge collaboration during text generation. Our comprehensive experiments demonstrate that MKS2 substantially augments the reasoning capabilities of LLMs in contexts necessitating physical or commonsense knowledge. It also delivers competitive results on image-text understanding multimodal benchmarks. The codes will be available at: https://github.com/HITsz-TMG/ MKS2-Multimodal-Knowledge-Storage-and-Sharing.

title: M2PP: Effective Path Planning Based on Multi-Phase Particle Swarm Optimization and Multi-Scenario Adaptative DWA_supp2-3654174.mp4
authors: Jun Sun
abstract: To address the challenge of autonomous navigation for mobile robots in complex environments, many recent path planning methods employ a two-layer motion framework that integrates both global and local planning. However, global planning algorithms based on evolutionary algorithms often yield suboptimal paths, primarily due to premature convergence and wasted iterations in infeasible regions. Meanwhile, local planning algorithms, particularly the dynamic window approach (DWA) and its variants, are frequently tailored to specific scenarios, limiting their generalizability. To address these issues, this paper proposes an effective path planning method, namely M2PP. The global planning algorithm in M2PP enhances particle swarm optimization (PSO) by introducing multiple new search phases, creating a multi-phase PSO that can quickly identify feasible global paths and thoroughly explore the sampling space. To effectively handle multiple scenarios in a more generalized manner, the local planning component, multi-scenario adaptative DWA, integrates two novel terms into its cost function, enhancing both static and dynamic obstacle avoidance. Extensive simulations demonstrate that multi-phase PSO exhibits strong performance and robustness, especially in highly complex scenarios, and multi-scenario adaptative DWA can generate safe and efficient local trajectories in hazardous conditions. Additionally, experiments deploying the M2PP method on a real-world mobile robot further confirm its feasibility.

title: Multi-Label Feature Selection by Maximum Affinity-Relevance, Maximum Affinity-Interaction and Minimum Affinity-Redundancy
authors: Jianhua Dai, Duo Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Multi-label feature selection solves the high-dimensional challenge problem in multi-label learning, and is widely used in pattern recognition, machine learning, and other related fields. However, most existing multi-label learning methods neglect the affinity between the features and the labels, which means the selected features may only provide categorization information for some of the labels rather than for all of them, resulting in one portion of labels obtaining sufficient categorization information, while another portion of labels obtains insufficient categorization information. In order to address this issue, we propose a new method for multi-label feature selection. Firstly, we propose the notion of affinity, which states that features are biased to provide categorical information for labels. Secondly, we propose three new feature evaluation metrics, affinity-relevance, affinity-redundancy, and affinity-interaction, which evaluate features in three dimensions from an affinity perspective. Thirdly, a new feature evaluation function called feature affinity significance, as well as a feature selection algorithm based on MARAImAR are proposed. Finally, experimental results on 15 multi-label benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms the other nine representative multi-label feature selection methods.

title: High-Refractive-Index Metasurface Integrated Circularly Polarized Wireless Power Transfer System with Extended Range and Misalignment Tolerance
authors: Nilanjan Dutta, Shrabani Mukherjee, Kaushik Mandal
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter presents the design and implementation of an orientation-independent wireless power transfer (WPT) system at 5.8 GHz ISM band, enhanced through integration of a high refractive index (HRI) metasurface (MTS). The transmitter employs a circularly polarized (CP) 2×2 array of diagonally fed rectangular microstrip patches to ensure rotational misalignment tolerance and improved gain. At the receiver side, a new hexagonal complementary star-shaped resonator (HCSSR)-based RI-MTS with a refractive index of 17.0 at 5.8 GHz is integrated with a compact CP receiving antenna. The HRI-MTS collimates the incident electromagnetic wave, reduces beam divergence, and enhances antenna gain without the enlargement of its physical aperture. Consequently, the proposed system achieves a peak power transfer efficiency (PTE) improvement from 21.04% to 28.91%, and extends the effective power transfer range (PTE ≤ 5%) from 87 mm to 198 mm. This WPT architecture simultaneously provides strong tolerance to rotational, lateral, and angular misalignments, demonstrating its suitability for powering distributed IoT nodes and compact portable devices.

title: GFZTD: A Multimodal Fusion-Driven 3-D Tropospheric Delay Prediction Model Coupling Self-Attention and ConvLSTM
authors: Yixin Zhu, Zhimin Sha, Pengzhi Wei, Shirong Ye, Pengfei Xia, Fangxin Hu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Tropospheric delay, for which water vapor is a major cause, is a significant source of error in Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS). This paper presents the GFZTD (Gray Figure-based Zenith Tropospheric Delay prediction) model, which is built on Convolutional Long Short-Term Memory Networks (ConvLSTM) and self-attention mechanisms. The model converts three-dimensional (3-D) zenith tropospheric delay (ZTD) grid products into multi-layer two-dimensional grayscale images for predictive analysis. Utilizing Global Forecast System (GFS) and ERA5 data from southeastern China and its adjacent seas in 2023, the GFZTD model is trained through seasonal slicing and stratification by altitude. This approach generates high spatio-temporal resolution ZTD 3-D grid products in near real-time. To evaluate the grid prediction results, ERA5 is used as the truth, with an overall RMSE of 1.35 cm, representing improvements of 26.5% and 71.0% over ZTD derived from GFS and GPT3 (Global Pressure and Temperature 3), respectively. The model also successfully mitigates regional extreme prediction errors in complex terrain environments for GFS. Additionally, when using VMF3 (Vienna Mapping Functions 3) post-processing products to assess ZTD prediction values at various stations, the GFZTD model shows an average root mean square error (RMSE) of 1.49 cm. This result indicates improvements of 13.1% and 69.4% compared to GFS and GPT3, respectively, underscoring the model's applicability at the station scale.

title: Fault-Tolerant Independent Pole Control Scheme of Zigzag MMC for Bipolar MVDC Distribution Systems
authors: Dong-Joon Kim, Jaeyeon Park, Yeonjoo Hong, Shenghui Cui
abstract: This paper presents a fault-tolerant independent pole control scheme for a zigzag modular multilevel converter (MMC) targeting bipolar medium-voltage direct-current (MVDC) distribution systems. An MMC which adopts a zigzag transformer as an AC grid interface transformer, namely zigzag MMC, has inherent bipole operation capability with unbalanced loads of positive and negative poles on the DC side. Nevertheless, this topology has not been thoroughly investigated for its ability to maintain independent control of each pole in the case of a fault in the other. With a conventional MMC control which relies on normal operation of both poles, a fault in a single pole is likely to impact the overall operation of the converter. To tackle this problem, the proposed control scheme separates the arm current controllers and energy balancing controllers within upper and lower arms individually. Additional power reference coupling is introduced to indirectly inject circulating currents when both poles are healthy like the conventional MMC. When a single pole fault occurs, a seamless energy-balancing mode transition can be achieved by modifying inputs to current reference calculators. An AC-side single line-to-ground (SLG) fault ride through (FRT) strategy can also be integrated without compromising the independence of both poles. A point-to-point zigzag-MMC based bipolar MVDC distribution system is tested by controller hardware-in-the-loop (CHIL) test setup. The test results under single pole-to-ground (PtG) fault and AC SLG fault validate the effectiveness of the proposed control scheme. Moreover, experimental results using a downscaled MMC prototype and a zigzag transformer further demonstrate the performance of the proposed control scheme under abrupt single-pole blocking and AC SLG fault conditions.

title: DPD-DEMD: Denoising Prior Guided Weakly Supervised Image Domain Dual-Energy Material Decomposition
authors: Xinyun Zhong, Xu Zhuo, Tianling Lyu, Yikun Zhang, Qianjin Feng, Guotao Quan, Xu Ji, Yang Chen
abstract: Dual-energy material decomposition is widely used in clinical diagnosis, especially for material characterization. However, conventional image-domain methods suffer from noise amplification, thus reducing signal-to-noise ratio and compromising diagnostic accuracy. Although deep learning approaches have shown significant progress, they often require high-quality paired or unpaired labels, limiting their clinical application. To address these issues, this work explores the feasibility of weakly supervised methods and proposes a denoising prior guided weakly supervised learning framework, DPD-DEMD, to achieve high-accuracy image-domain dual-energy material decomposition. DPD-DEMD utilizes pretrained CT denoising models to construct robust priors for our dual energy material decomposition task. Furthermore, we propose an adaptive confidence mask mechanism for pseudo label generation and a multi-prior fusion strategy, thereby substantially improving the stability and reliability of the weakly supervised learning process. In addition, we fully exploit the correlation between dual energy images and further propose global-local regularization loss to improve the material decomposition accuracy. Extensive experiments conducted on both simulated and clinical datasets verify the superior performance and robustness of the proposed method, thereby demonstrating its potential clinical value in material decomposition. Our code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/zhongxinyun/DPD-DEMD.git</uri>.

title: Game-Based Driver–Automation Cooperative Control Considering Driver Neuromuscular Delay
authors: Jun Liu, Hongyan Guo, Hong Chen, Dongpu Cao, Zhenhai Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: A game-based cooperative steering control (GCSC) approach is introduced to facilitate effective collaboration between human drivers and automation, incorporating the neuromuscular delay inherent in human responses. In this framework, a dynamic coordination between driver and automation goals is achieved through the establishment of a game equilibrium in instances of driver and automation conflict. In response to the challenges posed by frequent modifications in driving weights and their subsequent burden on human drivers, this article proposes a strategy that integrates fixed initial weights with dynamic adjustments to driver–automation driving weights. Moreover, a comprehensive evaluation method including subjective and objective evaluation indexes is proposed. Different drivers are invited to perform virtual driving experiments, and the experimental results are analyzed by the proposed evaluation method. It is concluded that the driver’s driving weight should be kept at a high level during cooperative steering control when the driver’s intention cannot be perfectly obtained, and the determination of the driving weight should also consider the driver’s driving skills.

title: R-VoxelMap: Accurate Voxel Mapping With Recursive Plane Fitting for Online LiDAR Odometry_supp1-3653337.mp4
authors: Shiyong Zhang
abstract: This paper proposes R-VoxelMap, a novel voxel mapping method that constructs accurate voxel maps using a geometry-driven recursive plane fitting strategy to enhance the localization accuracy of online LiDAR odometry. VoxelMap and its variants typically fit and check planes using all points in a voxel, which may lead to plane parameter deviation caused by outliers, over segmentation of large planes, and incorrect merging across different physical planes. To address these issues, R-VoxelMap utilizes a geometry-driven recursive construction strategy based on an outlier detect-and-reuse pipeline. Specifically, for each voxel, accurate planes are first fitted while separating outliers using random sample consensus (RANSAC). The remaining outliers are then propagated to deeper octree levels for recursive processing, ensuring a detailed representation of the environment. In addition, a point distribution-based validity check algorithm is devised to prevent erroneous plane merging. Extensive experiments on diverse open-source LiDAR(-inertial) simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) datasets validate that our method achieves higher accuracy than other state-of-the-art approaches, with comparable efficiency and memory usage. Code will be available on GitHub.

title: Highly Undersampled MRI Reconstruction via a Single Posterior Sampling of Diffusion Models
authors: Jin Liu, Qing Lin, Zhuang Xiong, Shanshan Shan, Chunyi Liu, Min Li, Feng Liu, G. Bruce Pike, Hongfu Sun, Yang Gao
abstract: Incoherent k-space undersampling and deep learning-based reconstruction methods have shown great success in accelerating MRI. However, the performance of most previous methods will degrade dramatically under high acceleration factors, e.g., 8× or higher. Recently, denoising diffusion models (DM) have demonstrated promising results in solving this issue; however, one major drawback of the DM methods is the long inference time due to a dramatic number of iterative reverse posterior sampling steps. In this work, a Single Step Diffusion Model-based reconstruction framework, namely SSDM-MRI, is proposed for restoring MRI images from highly undersampled k-space. The proposed method achieves one-step reconstruction by first training a conditional DM and then iteratively distilling this model four times using an iterative selective distillation algorithm, which works synergistically with a shortcut reverse sampling strategy for model inference. Comprehensive experiments were carried out on both publicly available fastMRI brain and knee images, as well as an in-house multi-echo GRE (QSM) subject. Overall, the results showed that SSDM-MRI outperformed other methods in terms of numerical metrics (e.g., PSNR and SSIM), error maps, image fine details, and latent susceptibility information hidden in MRI phase images. In addition, the reconstruction time for a 320×320 brain slice of SSDM-MRI is only 0.45 second, which is only comparable to that of a simple U-net, making it a highly effective solution for MRI reconstruction tasks.

title: Enhanced BER-Analysis-Based Adaptive Resource Allocation in SDN-Controlled Multi-User NOMA-OFDM VLC Systems
authors: Chengju Hu, Jianhang Li, Yinan Niu, Jian Zhao
abstract: We propose a novel multi-user resource allocation algorithm for non-orthogonal multiple access orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (NOMA-OFDM) visible light communication (VLC) systems. The proposed algorithm is based on the bit-error-rate analysis of the NOMA signal and solving a non-convex optimization problem employing successive convex approximation and block coordinate descent techniques. A VLC system with a software-defined-network (SDN) controlled real-time transmitter is developed to verify the proposed algorithm. 86–217Mbit/s experiments, with both homogeneous and heterogeneous receivers for users including avalanche photodiodes and silicon photomultipliers, show that the system can respond dynamically to the change of user demands and channel state information. The proposed algorithm exhibits better performance and user fairness than existing algorithms.

title: Downlink Rate Splitting Opportunistic Multiple Access for Satellite-Terrestrial Integrated Networks
authors: Xi-Ran Zhang, Wen-Bin Sun, Zhaolin Zhang, Ling Wang, Ang Gao, Wei-Xiao Meng, Victor C. M. Leung
abstract: With the advantages of wide coverage and strong resource collaboration capabilities, satellite-terrestrial integrated networks has become a potential transmission scheme in the sixth generation (6G) communication system. To ensure flexible and seamless coverage, multi-beam scheme is widely used. Meanwhile, with the limitation of resources, multiple access techniques are introduced into satellite-terrestrial integrated networks for providing services to multiple users simultaneously. Non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA), a popular multiple access technique that utilizes power domain superposition to significantly improve system performance, is widely employed. In order to achieve flexible interference management and further enhance spectral efficiency (SE) performance, rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) is proposed, which divides information streams into common parts and private parts. For satellite-terrestrial integrated networks, due to specific frequency band constraints and complexity of feedback link construction, channel estimation and information feedback are particularly difficult. Therefore, we consider introducing opportunistic selection into the existing RSMA scheme and propose a novel rate splitting opportunistic multiple access (RSOMA) system for satellite-terrestrial integrated networks. The proposed system utilizes opportunistic selection to combat imperfect CSI and obtain better SE performance. Statistical characteristics of equivalent channels are attained, and we reveal the closed-forms of SE and BER. To maximize the sum SE, a non-convex optimization problem is constructed and is separated into three sub-issues. Finally, a resource iteration optimization algorithm is applied to derive the optimal parameters. Numerical results reveal that the proposed RSOMA system can obtain excellent SE performance without perfect CSI.

title: A Sub-Threshold Oscillator-Based High-Accuracy Temperature Sensor With Tolerance to Supply Fluctuation and Device Aging
authors: Wei Wang, Yumin Su, Shayok Dutta, Liwen Jiang, Zhiyu Chen, Zhanghao Yu, Caleb Kemere, Kaiyuan Yang
abstract: Accurate, low-power, and compact temperature sensors are demanded in a wide range of biomedical, environmental, and industrial sensing applications. This article presents an accurate and precise CMOS temperature sensor based on a sub-threshold ring oscillator (RO) in 180 nm. The sensing core employs a five-stage super cut-off contention-free (SCCF) delay cell to closely mimic the temperature dependency of a single MOSFET, minimizing the errors in current-to-frequency conversion and achieving a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${-} 0.065~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${+} 0.061~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C inaccuracy after 2-point calibration and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\pm } 0.26~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C after 1-point calibration from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${-} 20~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$100~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C. Meanwhile, a self-biased 3-transistor (3T) header significantly reduces the supply line sensitivity to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.02~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C/V and achieves less than <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.2~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C temperature drift after more than 180 h of accelerated aging. The aging-induced drift is reduced to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.11~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C with a calibration after 30 h of pre-aging. Additionally, this work introduces an adaptive uniform resolution counter to maintain a consistent and programmable resolution across the wide temperature range, despite the sub-threshold RO’s exponential dependency on temperature. The prototyping sensor in 180-nm CMOS consumes only 33 nW at <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$20~{^{\circ }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C and occupies 0.028-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text {mm}^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> area. Beyond standard circuit testing, the 1-pt calibrated sensor was validated in a multi-day in vivo animal body temperature tracking experiment and outperformed off-the-shelf solutions.

title: Securing Symmetric Encryption Based on Substitution-Permutation Network Against White-Box Attacks
authors: Yang Shi, Tianchen Gao, Qiaoliang Ouyang, Junqing Liang, Mianhong Li, Jiayao Gao, Xiapu Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Extensive research has been done on the security of symmetric encryption algorithms in the black-box attack contexts, where the execution platforms are supposed to be secure. Recent studies intend to secure encryption algorithms in a more challenging but widely adopted scenario, the white-attack context (WBAC), where the adversaries have full visibility of the implementations of cryptosystems and full control over execution platforms. Various of approaches for protecting symmetric encryption algorithms in the WBAC have been proposed. Unfortunately, most existing approaches have been broken. This paper proposes a novel approach for securing symmetric encryption algorithms based on substitution-permutation network (SPN). Our key idea is to incorporate additional secret components into lookup tables to expand and dramatically change the inner states of encryption. Unlike existing approaches, these components do not need to be annihilated in adjacent rounds, and the ciphertext remains essentially unchanged. To recover the plaintext, only simple operations and the standard decryption algorithm are required. Our approach can be applied to protect SPN-based symmetric encryption algorithms such as AES. Security analysis indicates that the approach is expected to be resistant to both existing and unknown attacks. Furthermore, experimental evaluation shows that our approach performs well on various platforms.

title: Corrigendum: Life Cycle Assessment of Edge Data Centers: Case Study in Presence of Renewable Energy and Refurbished Servers
