authors: Lianyu Hu, Mudi Jiang, Junjie Dong, Xinying Liu, Zengyou He
abstract: None

title: A MLP-BiGRU Model Based Dynamic Displacement Estimation Method for Multi State Indoor Positioning
authors: Hongliang Chen, Hao Wang, Tao Dong, Jinhui Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: To achieve accurate multi state 3D indoor positioning, a dynamic displacement estimation (DDE) method based on Multilayer Perceptron-Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit (MLP-BiGRU) is proposed and integrated into the error-state extended Kalman filter (ES-EKF). MLP-BiGRU uses self-built IMU and plantar pressure dataset to extract more overlooked features for dual task classification of four gaits and six phases. The DDE method estimates the leg length and inter step displacement in different gaits through the displacement of the center of plantar pressure (COP) between each phase, and uses them as ES-EKF observations to assist zero velocity update (ZUPT) to correct positioning errors. The experimental results show that the proposed DDE method achieves a relative position accuracy of 0.51%, which decreased by 80.27% compared to the method without using DDE.

title: Adaptive In Adapter: Boosting Open-Vocabulary Semantic Segmentation with Adaptive Dropout Adapter
authors: Changwei Wang, Wenhao Xu, Rongtao Xu, Zherui Zhang, Shibiao Xu, Jiguang Zhang, Xiaoqiang Teng, Weiliang Meng, Xiaopeng Zhang
abstract: Open-vocabulary semantic segmentation is a challenging multimedia task that requires segmentation and recognition of unseen word classes during the testing phase. Recent works bridge the gap between closed and open-vocabulary recognition by introducing large-scale visual language models such as CLIP with cross-modal alignment capabilities. To preserve multimodal alignment capabilities, it is common to freeze the parameters of the CLIP and then add additional learnable components such as adapters to expand to downstream tasks. However, for the open-vocabulary semantic segmentation task, the plain adapter suffers from overfitting the closed-vocabulary classes and impairs performance on the open-vocabulary unseen classes. In addition, since CLIP is trained to perform image-level alignment can cause the network to over-focus on partially discriminative regions, resulting in incomplete segmentation masks. To alleviate the above problems, we introduce adaptive dropout adapters to release the Adaptive In Adapter (i.e. AIA) from the following two aspects: i) A Generalization Feature Selection Adapter (GFSA) is proposed to improve the generalization of network over unseen classes. ii) A Discriminative Region Mask Adapter (DRMA) is proposed for retrofitting CLIP backbone, has provided region free biased features for segmentation mask generation. Meanwhile, our proposed AIA achieves the current state-of-the-art performance on several open-vocabulary semantic segmentation benchmarks. Code is available at https://github.com/clearxu/AIA.

title: Improving Stock Market Prediction Accuracy Using LSTM Neural Networks with Financial Indicators
authors: Aaron Tanujaya Didi, David Christian, Nikita Ananda Putri Masaling, Andry Chowanda
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Traditional forecasting models often fail in volatile financial markets. To address this gap, our research develops and validates an enhanced Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network. The model's novelty lies not merely in using indicators, but in demonstrating the significant performance gains from a comprehensive suite of 17 financial technical indicators, synergistically combined with a bagging ensemble method, moving beyond a reliance on raw price data alone. To validate its effectiveness, we tested the model using a decade of daily S&P 500 data (2015-2024) and compared its performance against both a traditional ARIMA model and a standard LSTM. Our findings were compelling. The enhanced model proved to be significantly more powerful, not only improving its ability to predict the market's direction but also cutting the Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) by a notable 27% when compared to the traditional ARIMA model. Our conclusion is clear: integrating financial indicators into an LSTM network creates a superior forecasting tool. This approach provides a tangible advantage for investors aiming to make more informed decisions in volatile markets.

title: Exploring the Role of Task-Technology Fit and Performance Expectancy in Mobile Learning Adoption
authors: Dinar Mutiara Kusumo Nugraheni, Ragil Saputra, Norjihan Abdul Ghani, Haidar Ali Laudza, Kevin Adi Santoso, Indra Purwanto
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Mobile-based online learning apps are now widely used, which has altered education by making it easier for students to get the academic resources they need when they need them. This study uses a unique paradigm that combines the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology and Task-Technology Fit to look at how these two factors affect students' willingness to use mobile learning apps. This study suggested and tested four hypotheses: 1) Task characteristics (TAC) and technology characteristics (TEC) make TTF better; 2) TTF makes performance expectancy (PE) better; and 3) PE makes user adoption (UA) better. The study employed data from a survey of 100 students using a method called partial least squares structural equation modeling (PLS-SEM). The results indicated that both TAC and TEC made TTF much better. TTF also had a substantial effect on PE, which in turn had an effect on UA. This study's results reveal that TTF plays a function in connecting task-technology aspects with performance goals in mobile learning environments that had not been noticed before. This gives us a new way to look at how technology is used in schools. From a practical perspective, these findings suggest that educational app developers should prioritize creating features that align closely with students' specific learning tasks rather than focusing solely on advanced technological capabilities. The significant impact of both task and technology characteristics on task-technology fit indicates that successful mobile learning applications must be designed through thorough user research to understand actual academic workflows and requirements, ensuring that interface design, content delivery methods, and interactive features directly support students' learning activities.

title: Development of Iot Based Academic Information System Using Kanban Laravel Framework to Improve Community Services at Public High School Level
authors: Wahyul A. Syafei, Satyagraha Pakarti Gemilang, Agung Budi Prasetijo, Muhammad Taqiyuddin
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Contribution of Internet of Things (IoT) in education gives more crucial role in increasing the efficiency of academic data management and hence improving community services. It facilitates real-time information exchange among related parties and enhances the academic process at schools. Junior High School X, which is in the Demak district, still relies on conventional methods for recording data and academic records such as attendance, grades, and report cards. Using scattered books and Excel files causes business processes to run slowly, data processing to be difficult, and information exchange to lack transparency to the whole academic parties. This research aims to design an IoT-based academic information system that addresses issues such as scattered data, timeconsuming data summaries, etc. The system is developed using the Kanban Laravel framework. Function testing on the code shows that the actual results align with expected outcomes. Web load testing measures the server's performance in real-world simulation scenarios. The load testing indicates that the average response time ranges from 300 ms to 950 ms in simulations involving teachers and homeroom teachers. Further, the user acceptance test with satisfaction rate of 90.16 % indicates that the developed system is well received by respondents.

title: Enhanced CT Saturation Detection Based on Fault Current Decomposition and Digital Filtering
authors: Amir Haji-Mohammadi, Mohammad Mehdi Mobashsher, Majid Sanaye-Pasand
abstract: Accurate current transformer (CT) saturation identification is crucial for reliable power system protection. Conventional methods often struggle with CT detection accuracy under varying conditions, leading to relay malfunction. To address these limitations, this article presents a novel analytical approach that models fault current as the sum of three components: a sinusoidal term, a decaying dc term, and a saturation-induced error term. A tailored filter is designed to eliminate the sinusoidal component, enabling precise identification of saturation periods. The proposed method is validated through theoretical analysis, mathematical derivations, and simulations using the Jiles-Atherton hysteresis model in PSCAD, ensuring realistic CT behavior. Real-world fault records and experimental analysis are further utilized to assess the practical performance. Comparative analysis against the existing techniques demonstrates improved accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency. Experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the suggested method in practical scenarios, with successful operation in both ac and dc saturations identification. By improving CT saturation detection, this research enhances relay performance, reduces protection malfunction, and strengthens power system stability. The proposed approach offers a practical and computationally efficient solution for modern protection schemes, addressing key gaps in the existing methodologies.

title: Spatio-Semantic Enhanced Cascade Swin Detection Network for Infrared Maritime Targets
authors: Dongdong Ma, Shaohua Chen, Lili Dong, Tingkuo Chen, Wenhai Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: To address the issues of high missed detection rates in maritime infrared small and weak target detection łcaused by imbalanced target scales, strong ocean wave interference, and low signal-to-clutter ratiołthis paper proposes a convolutional neural network based on cascade fusion and local feature enhancement. Built on the CSPDarknet53 backbone network, the proposed network incorporates a structural tensor spatiotemporal information enhancement module and a dynamic context-aware attention semantic enhancement module to improve the representational capabilities of shallow spatial features and deep semantic features. Meanwhile, a hierarchical feature bidirectional symmetric fusion network and a scale-aware upsampling operator are designed to achieve effective interaction and reconstruction of multi-scale features. Additionally, Swin transformer is adopted as the detection head to enhance the modeling of long-range semantic dependencies.Experimental results demonstrate that on the self-constructed infrared maritime target dataset, the proposed network achieves a Precision of 0.865, a Recall of 0.875, and an F1-score of 0.870. These performance metrics outperform those of mainstream methods such as RLCM, PSTNN, Faster RCNN, YOLOv5s, YOLOv8s, and AGPCNet. Particularly, the proposed network exhibits high robustness and real-time performance in complex background environments and small/weak target detection tasks.

title: Improving Skin Cancer Classification with Dilated Convolutional VGG16 Networks
authors: Simeon Yuda Prasetyo, Abram Setyo Prabowo, Santy, Melkamu Hunegnaw Asmare, Clarissa Aditjakra, Clarawita
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Improving patient survival rates requires early and precise skin cancer detection, particularly in places with limited access to specialized dermatology services. By incorporating dilated convolution into the popular VGG16 model, this study suggests a modified convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture to enhance its classification ability on dermatoscopic images. Using the ISIC 2019 dataset containing over 25,000 skin lesion images with two main categories (cancerous and non-cancerous), the proposed model is evaluated against several standard CNN architectures such as VGG16, ResNet50, Xception, and ConvNeXt Base. Experimental results show that the VGG16 model with dilated convolution achieves the highest classification accuracy (82.9%) and the best F1-score for both cancer (0.843) and non-cancerous (0.814) classes, significantly outperforming the benchmark models. The use of dilated convolutions has been shown to expand the receptive field without increasing model complexity, allowing better multiscale feature extraction, especially for lesions with blurred boundaries. These findings suggest that dilated convolution modifications to classical CNN architectures can be a promising and computationally efficient strategy for deep learning-based skin cancer early detection systems.

title: Robust Point Cloud Registration via High-Dimensional Complex Kernel
authors: Kemeng Li, Hanghang Xu, Yinggang Wang, HongLi Zhang, Yijin Chen
abstract: Robust and efficient point cloud registration is fundamental to robotic perception tasks such as SLAM, 3D reconstruction, and autonomous navigation. Traditional methods often rely on fragile point correspondences and iterative optimization, struggling under conditions like poor initialization, partial overlap, and perceptual aliasing. We propose Complex Kernel Registration (CKR), a novel framework that replaces fragile point-level correspondences with a robust alignment of high-level block descriptors. CKR operates by establishing coarse matches between local block descriptors in a high-dimensional complex Hilbert space. CKR extracts compact 8D descriptors capturing both geometric structure and LiDAR reflectance, embeds them via Random Fourier Features, and estimates rigid transformations using Wirtinger gradient descent. This formulation bypasses explicit point matching, yielding fast, accurate, and robust registration, even in cluttered, occluded, and low-texture environments. Extensive experiments on real-world LiDAR datasets demonstrate that CKR outperforms classical and learning-based baselines in accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency, which is practical for deployment on resource-constrained robotic platforms without specialized hardware.

title: Detecting Unknown Cyberattacks on Traffic Management Center in C-ITS
authors: Seunghyun Jang, Jisu Kim, Hyeongy Shon, Chanmin Park, MyungKeun Yoon
abstract: Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems (C-ITS) improve road safety and traffic efficiency by enabling real-time data exchange among vehicles, infrastructure, and other road users. Given the critical role of the Traffic Management Center (TMC) in orchestrating this ecosystem, its network infrastructure must be resilient to cyber threats. While prior studies have primarily focused on securing vehicles and roadside units, the detection of unknown cyberattacks targeting the TMC remains largely unexplored, and few studies have utilized real-world datasets for this purpose. This article presents a C-ITS demonstration project deployed in South Korea and proposes Flow Identification for C-ITS (FIC), a lightweight anomaly detection method designed to identify previously unseen cyberattacks on the TMC. FIC compresses large volumes of benign network flows into a compact set of prototype flows. Since unknown attacks are unlikely to conform to these prototypes, abnormal flows can be efficiently detected through simple membership testing - eliminating the need for computationally intensive machine learning models. Experimental results on realworld TMC traffic data demonstrate that FIC effectively detects cyberattack attempts with high accuracy and minimal computational overhead.

title: Hybrid Statistical and Machine Learning Approach for Forecasting the Global Food Price Index Based on Oil Prices
authors: Christopher Andreas, Yohana Jocelyn Guntur, Felicia Joshlyn Purnomo, Satria Adi Nugraha, Rudi Limantara, Andreas Jodhinata
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Food price inflation has become a significant global challenge, adversely affecting human well-being and emerging as a key concern within the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). This inflation is closely linked to the dynamics of the global food price index. Thus, accurately forecasting this index is crucial, particularly when accounting for exogenous factors such as global oil prices. This study aims to predict the global food price index by comparing three analytical approaches: a statistical method (ARIMAX), machine learning methods (Random Forest and XGBoost), and a hybrid approach that integrates both. Parameter estimation was conducted using the Least Squares method for ARIMAX and Grid Search for the machine learning models. The models were evaluated using Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) to assess predictive performance. The results indicate that global oil prices have a significant influence on the food price index. Moreover, the hybrid ARIMAX-XGBoost model demonstrated the best performance, with RMSE and MAPE values of 0.02 and 1.95%, respectively, outperforming each individual approach. These findings highlight that integrating statistical and machine learning techniques enhances prediction accuracy for the food price index influenced by global oil prices, thereby supporting more effective policy decision-making in addressing the impacts of global food inflation.

title: Transient Response Analysis and System Fault Ride-through Capability Optimization of HVDC Based on Hybrid Commutated Converter
authors: Jianchao Ma, Lerong Hong, Xiaoping Zhou, Lingfeng Deng, Hanting Peng, Renlong Zhu, Yandong Chen, Honglin Ouyang
abstract: Modifying the inverter of line-commutated converter- based high-voltage direct current (LCC-HVDC) to hybrid commutated converter (HCC) is currently a highly effective solution for mitigating the risk of commutation failure (CF). This paper investigates the transient performance of HCC from five perspectives while retaining the LCC-HVDC control system. Since constant extinction angle (CEA) controller leads to significant reduction in power transmission, constant voltage (CV) controller is considered a more appropriate choice as the main controller during AC faults. In addition, the extreme case of insufficient forced commutation capacity leading to CF is considered. It is revealed for the first time that the voltage clamping effect of the arrester will cause a new CF phenomenon. There will be no short circuit on the DC side and the fault current is greatly reduced. This leads to insufficient regulation capability of the CV controller, resulting in continuous CFs. Given the limited fault ride-through capability of the selected CV controller, this paper proposes an adaptive order regulation control (AORC) based on expected reactive power. It can adjust the DC current and voltage in a targeted manner according to AC faults, and determine the maximum allowable upper limit of the firing angle. This improves the reliability of HCC in resisting CF. Under extreme cases, it also effectively prevents the continuous CFs. The simulation results in PSCAD/EMTDC verify the theoretical analyses and the proposed control method.

title: Numerical Experiments on Adaptive Step-Size Coordinate Descent in Online Convex Optimization
authors: Tara Afri Melandari, Sutrisno, Farikhin
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: We propose the Adaptive Step-Size Coordinate Descent (AS-CD) algorithm for online convex optimization in dynamic environments. Unlike fixed step size methods, AS-CD adapts step sizes and selects coordinates via the Gauss–Southwell rule, enabling better responsiveness to non-stationary optima. Motivated by practical needs in machine learning and adaptive control, this paper provides numerical validation showing that AS-CD consistently achieves lower dynamic regret and faster convergence than Fixed Step-Size Coordinate Descent (FS-CD). Experiments on Quadratic, Least Squares, Logistic Regression, Hinge Loss, and Log–Sum–Exp functions demonstrate robustness across smooth, non-smooth, general, and strongly convex settings. Notably, AS-CD approaches near-constant regret in Least Squares and achieves sublinear regret in broader scenarios. These findings highlight its potential for high-dimensional, time-varying optimization, with theoretical analysis and regret bounds left for future work.

title: A Tracking Mode Selection Scheme for Multiple Target Tracking in Multiple Radar Systems
authors: Peng Zhang, Junkun Yan, Kexin Li, Jia Liang, Lin Ma, Hongwei Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Existing resource allocation methods typically model adaptable radar parameters as continuous optimization variables, which may mismatch with discrete radar tracking modes setting, and prove challenging for practical implementation. To promote the application of resource management methods, this paper designs a tracking mode selection scheme (TMSS) for multiple radar systems (MRS), where tracking mode selection adjusts the tracking capabilities of the radar systems by altering their power parameters. The proposed approach primarily formulates an integer optimization model to select suitable tracking modes, thereby changing power resources to enhance the efficiency of limited resource utilization. We first define the discrete tracking modes of radars based on power resources and establish a tracking accuracy evaluation criterion by incorporating these modes into the Bayesian Cramér Rao Lower Bound. By adopting the discrete performance metric, the mode selection problem is constructed as an integer optimization model to balance power consumption with accuracy. A two-step method including relaxation and rounding techniques utilizes the resource utilization characteristics of the various tracking modes to attain efficient solutions to the tracking mode selection problem. Experimental results demonstrate that the TMSS adapts to the discrete tracking modes of MRS, achieving better balance between power resource conservation and solution efficiency.

title: User-to-User Clustering, Channel Estimation & Cross-Link Interference Mitigation for Dynamic TDD Systems
authors: Martin Andersson, Anubhab Chowdhury, Erik G. Larsson
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: In dynamic time-division duplexing (TDD) systems, half-duplex access points (APs) scheduled either in uplink (UL) or downlink (DL), simultaneously serve users operating in UL and DL on the same time-frequency resources. This incurs cross-link interference from APs operating in DL to APs in UL, and similarly from users operating in UL to users in DL. In this paper, we develop a scalable method for UL-user-to-DL-user interference (UUI) mitigation in dynamic TDD networks. To this end, we note that the UUI observed at each DL user will be predominantly caused by the UL users in its close vicinity. Hence, we propose to form local clusters of UL users for each DL user, including only the UL users that are expected to cause significant UUI to the DL user. Then, we present a graph-coloring-based pilot reuse algorithm that ensures orthogonal pilots among the UL users within the local clusters of each DL user, while maximizing the pilot reuse (i.e., minimizing the pilot length) for scalability. Further, we introduce beamformed DL pilots to estimate effective DL channels (the physical DL channel multiplied by the DL precoding matrix), which together with estimated user-to-user channels enable the multi-antenna DL users to design combining vectors maximizing their signal-to-interference-and-noise ratios, by taking both desired signal amplification and UUI suppression into consideration. We derive an achievable DL spectral efficiency with our proposed pilot schemes and combining vectors. Numerical results show the effectiveness of our proposed UUI mitigation scheme, both in terms of pilot overhead reduction and UUI suppression with our designed combining vectors.

title: Dual Perception Detector for Ship Detection in SAR Images
authors: Ming Tong, Shenghua Fan, Jiu Jiang, Hezhi Sun, Jisan Yang, Chu He
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Recently, detectors based on deep learning have boosted the State-of-the-Art (SOTA) of application on ship detection in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images. However, constructing discriminative feature from scattering of background and distinguishing contour of ship precisely still present challenging subject to the inherent scattering mechanism of SAR. In this article, a dual-branch detection framework with perception of scattering characteristic and geometric contour is introduced to deal with the problem. Firstly, a scattering characteristic perception branch is proposed to fit the scattering distribution of SAR ship through conditional diffusion model, which introduces learnable scattering feature. Secondly, a convex contour perception branch is designed as two-stage coarse-to-fine pipeline to delimit the irregular boundary of ship by learning scattering key points. Finally, a cross-token integration module following Bayesian framework is introduced to couple features of scattering and texture adaptively to learn construction of discriminative feature. Furthermore, comprehensive experiments on three authoritative SAR datasets for oriented ship detection demonstrate the effectiveness of proposed method.

title: Driving Behaviour Classification and Risk Quantification via Multi-Sensor Machine Learning: From Simulation to Reality
authors: Arash Abarghooei, Mojtaba Ahmadi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Driver behaviours such as aggression and distraction are leading contributors to traffic accidents worldwide. This paper presents a real-time driver behaviour detection system utilizing a multi-modal sensing approach that combines in-vehicle sensors (CAN bus signals, IMU, ADAS perception outputs) with low-cost physiological measurements (heart rate, steering wheel grip force). The proposed framework employs machine learning models to classify and quantify safe, aggressive, and distracted driving behaviours using Gaussian Support Vector Machines (SVM) for classification and Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) for risk-level estimation aligned with accident probability metrics. A comprehensive analysis of feature selection, sensor combinations, and optimal time windows shows that reliable detection can be achieved using 3–12 seconds of driver observation, supporting online deployment. To validate the generalizability of the approach beyond simulation, a custom-built data logger was deployed in real-world controlled driving scenarios that replicated aggressive and distracted behaviours under safe and ethically approved conditions. The models trained solely on simulator data achieved over 92% accuracy in detecting aggressive driving and more than 88% accuracy for distraction detection when applied to real-vehicle data. These results confirm the robustness of the proposed system for practical implementation in driver assistance and telematics applications.

title: Robust Beamforming for RIS Assisted Wireless Networked Control Systems
authors: Biao Ma, Min Lin, Zining Wang, Lve Han, Jin-Yuan Wang, Jiangzhou Wang
abstract: The complex electromagnetic environment prevalent in industrial production severely affects the performance of wireless networked control system (WNCS). In this context, we propose a robust beamforming scheme to address this problem, where the controller is equipped with multi-antenna and a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is deployed to enhance the wireless link quality. With this regard, we first adopt the pre-defined Lyapunov-like function to derive the control stability condition of the production devices. Then, a constrained optimization problem using the concept of communication and control co-design is formulated to minimize the total transmit power while guaranteeing the control stability of WNCS. Assuming that the imperfect channel state information is available, we exploit the fractional programming method to transform the control stability constraint into an outage constraint, and propose an alternative algorithm combining Bernstein inequality with first-order convex approximation to design the active beamformer of the controller and passive beamformer of the RIS. Finally, simulation results demonstrate that compared with the existing methods, our proposed scheme can significantly reduce the power consumption, provided that the control stability is guaranteed.

title: Non-Gradient Hash Factor Learning for High-Dimensional and Incomplete Data Representation Learning
authors: Di Wu, Shihui Li, Yi He, Xin Luo, Xinbo Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: High-dimensional and incomplete (HDI) data are ubiquitous in various Big Data-related industrial applications, such as drug innovation and recommender systems. Hash learning is the most efficient representation learning approach to extract hidden information from HDI data owing to its fast reasoning and low storage. However, an existing hash learning approach commonly employs gradient-based optimization techniques to address the discrete objective caused by the binary nature of hash factors, where the Quantization (i.e., quantizing the real values to binary codes) loss is inevitable, resulting in accuracy loss when representing HDI data. Motivated by these critical and vital issues, this paper proposes a non-gradient hash factor (NGHF) model with three-fold ideas: a) innovating a discrete differential evolution (DDE) algorithm able to simulate the continuous optimization via disabling bits of binary codes based on the projected Hamming dissimilarity, thus enabling an effective discrete optimizer, b) applying the proposed DDE algorithm to directly optimize the discrete learning objective of NGHF defined on HDI data, thereby facilitating its efficient and precise training without any Quantization loss, and c) theoretically proving the convergence of NGHF. As such, NGHF possesses high representation learning ability comparable to that of a real-valued model, making it able to achieve precise binary representation to HDI data. Extensive experimental results on nine real-world datasets demonstrate that NGHF significantly outperforms eight state-of-the-art hash learning models. Moreover, its accuracy is amazingly comparable to that of a real valued model for HDI data representation learning. Such results are inspiring for facilitating hash-learning models with both high accuracy and fast reasoning on HDI data, which is critical for industrial applications. Our source code is shared at the link: https://github.com/wudi1989/NGHF.

title: A Review of High-Power Medium Frequency Transformers in Medium Voltage Power Electronics: State of the Art, Challenges, and Solutions
authors: Zhicheng Guo, Binhong Cao, Chen Chen, Alex Q. Huang
abstract: Medium frequency transformers (MFTs) have emerged as a key enabling technology in medium voltage (MV) power electronics systems, supporting applications such as solid state transformers (SST), power electronic traction transformers (PETT), medium voltage direct current (MVDC) power distribution. This review provides a comprehensive overview of high-power MFTs, focusing on their state of the art, applications, technical challenges, and current research solutions. The paper surveys key considerations including core materials, core shapes, winding technologies, winding structures, insulation considerations, dielectric materials, electric field stress grading materials, and cooling technologies. Specifically targeted at modern MV power electronics, this paper discusses the challenges and solutions in MFT insulation design and test. The topics include complex voltage stress and electric field distribution, partial discharge under medium frequency high dv/dt waveforms, and insulation test standards which are critical to enhance the performance, reliability, and development of high-power MFTs in MV applications.

title: Robust Beamforming for Pinching-Antenna Systems
authors: Mingjun Sun, Chongjun Ouyang, Shaochuan Wu, Yuanwei Liu
abstract: Pinching-antenna system (PASS) mitigates large-scale path loss by enabling flexible placement of pinching antennas (PAs) along the dielectric waveguide. However, most existing studies assume perfect channel state information (CSI), overlooking the impact of channel uncertainty. This paper addresses this gap by proposing a robust beamforming framework for both lossy and lossless waveguides. For baseband beamforming, the lossy case yields an second-order cone programming-based solution, while the lossless case admits a closed-form solution via maximum ratio transmission. The PAs' positions in both cases are optimized through the Gauss-Seidel-based method. Numerical results validate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm and demonstrate that PASS exhibits superior robustness against channel uncertainty compared with conventional fixed-antenna systems. Notably, its worst-case achievable rate can even exceed the fixed-antenna baseline under perfect CSI.

title: Modeling and Simulation of an Off-Grid Hybrid Microgrid System: A Case Study of a Kavalur Rural Social Community
authors: K. Karunanithi, S. Ramesh, S. P. Raja, S. Saravanan
publish: IEEE Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Magazine
abstract: In recent days, a spotlight has been thrown on microgrids as there has been more evolution of software systems, increasing customers’ thirst for sustainability, reliability, and cost predictability. For these reasons, there is a need for development of microgrids in remote areas. In this article, a hybrid microgrid system for a remote locality in the southern part of India, specifically Kavalur, Tamil Nadu, is presented. The primary objective is to perform sizing and cost optimization of the designed system. In order to design this system, commercial software named “HOMER Pro” was used to obtain the optimum solutions. The hybrid system consisted of a wind generator (WG), a solar photovoltaic (PV) array, a diesel generator (DG) system, and a battery storage system to fulfill the load requirements of the particular area. The sensitivity analysis was also carried out by considering different PV derated output powers at two different hub heights. It was found that the design consisting of a PV array, a wind turbine, a DG set, and a lead acid battery gave better optimum results, with a total net present cost (NPC) of US<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}$</tex-math></inline-formula>340,287 with a PV derating of 80% and a hub height of 50 m. The cost of energy (CoE) was estimated as US<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}$</tex-math></inline-formula>0.247 per unit.

title: Dual Self-Supervised Deep Graph Clustering
authors: Qianqian Wang, Bowen Zhao, Zihao Zhang, Quanxue Gao, Licheng Jiao
abstract: Contrastive deep graph clustering has garnered significant attention owing to its robust representation capacity and superior clustering performance. However, existing contrastive deep graph clustering methods typically treat different views of the same node as positive samples and different views of different nodes as negative samples, neglecting the importance of various nodes and the structural information of the graph. To alleviate this issue, we propose a novel method called Dual Self-Supervised Deep Graph Clustering (DSDGC). Specifically, to generate different views, we employ unshared Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs) to project the pre-processed graph into various subspaces as different views. Then, we design the first self-supervised learning module, i.e., a weighted contrastive module, by introducing the cross-view similarity matrix as a weight matrix for positive/negative sample selection to bring similar nodes closer while pushing dissimilar nodes apart. Moreover, we align the semantic labels with high-confidence clustering pseudo-labels, forming the second self-supervised module, to further guarantee the clustering reliability. Extensive experiments on six benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed DSDGC method outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Scheduling Techniques of AI Models on Modern Heterogeneous Edge GPU—A Critical Review
authors: Ashiyana Abdul Majeed, Mahmoud Meribout, Safa Mohammed Sali
abstract: In recent years, the development of specialized edge computing devices has significantly increased, driven by the growing demand for artificial intelligence (AI) models. These devices, such as the NVIDIA Jetson series, must efficiently handle increased data processing and storage requirements. However, despite these advancements, there remains a lack of frameworks that automate the optimal execution of the deep neural network (DNN). Therefore, efforts have been made to create schedulers that can manage complex data processing needs while ensuring the efficient utilization of all available accelerators within these devices, including the CPU, GPU, deep learning accelerator (DLA), programmable vision accelerator (PVA), and video image compositor (VIC). Such schedulers would maximize the performance of edge computing systems, which is crucial in resource-constrained environments. This article aims to comprehensively review the various DNN schedulers implemented on NVIDIA Jetson devices. It examines their methodologies, performance, and effectiveness in addressing the demands of modern AI workloads. By analyzing these schedulers, this review highlights the current state of the research in the field. It identifies future research and development areas, further enhancing edge computing devices’ capabilities.

title: Power Source Allocation for RIS-aided Integrating Sensing, Communication, and Power Transfer Communication Systems Based on NOMA
authors: Yue Xiu, Yang Zhao, Chenfei Xie, Fatma Benkhelifa, Songjie Yang, Wanting Lyu, Chadi Assi, Ning Wei
abstract: The integration of sensing, communication, and power transfer (ISCPT) has emerged as a promising paradigm for energy- and spectrum-efficient 6G networks. Recent studies have revealed that sensing accuracy, achievable rate, and harvested energy inherently exhibit conflicting design requirements and form a nontrivial trade-off region. However, existing integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) and simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) schemes typically optimize at most two of these functionalities and lack a unified resource-allocation framework that can flexibly balance all three under stringent power budgets. Motivated by this gap, we consider a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided ISCPT system that employs non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) to support multi-user connectivity. In the proposed design, the RIS reshapes the wireless propagation environment in an energy-efficient manner to enhance both sensing and power transfer, while NOMA provides power-domain multiplexing to improve spectral efficiency and user scalability. We formulate a total transmit power minimization problem by jointly optimizing the base-station beamforming, RIS phase shifts, power splitting (PS) ratios, and NOMA decoding order under quality-of-service (QoS), Cramér–Rao-bound-based sensing accuracy, and energy-harvesting constraints. The resulting problem is highly non-convex due to the coupling among the design variables. To solve it efficiently, we develop a block coordinate descent (BCD)-based algorithm that leverages semidefinite relaxation (SDR), successive convex approximation (SCA), and the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM). Simulation results verify that the proposed RIS-aided NOMA-ISCPT framework significantly reduces the base-station transmit power while achieving favorable trade-offs among communication reliability, sensing precision, and energy-transfer efficiency.

title: HANS-Net: Hyperbolic Convolution and Adaptive Temporal Attention for Accurate and Generalizable Liver and Tumor Segmentation in CT Imaging
authors: Arefin Ittesafun Abian, Ripon Kumar Debnath, Md. Abdur Rahman, Mohaimenul Azam Khan Raiaan, Md Rafiqul Islam, Asif Karim, Reem E. Mohamed, Sami Azam
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Accurate liver and tumor segmentation on abdominal CT images is critical for reliable diagnosis and treatment planning, but remains challenging due to complex anatomical structures, variability in tumor appearance, and limited annotated data. To address these issues, we introduce Hyperbolic-convolutions Adaptive-temporal-attention with Neural-representation and Synaptic-plasticity Network (HANS-Net), a novel segmentation framework that synergistically combines hyperbolic convolutions for hierarchical geometric representation, a wavelet-inspired decomposition module for multi-scale texture learning, a biologically motivated synaptic plasticity mechanism for adaptive feature enhancement, and an implicit neural representation branch to model fine-grained and continuous anatomical boundaries. Additionally, we incorporate uncertainty-aware Monte Carlo dropout to quantify prediction confidence and lightweight temporal attention to improve inter-slice consistency without sacrificing efficiency. Extensive evaluations of the LiTS dataset demonstrate that HANS-Net achieves a mean Dice score of 93.26%, an IoU of 88.09%, an average symmetric surface distance (ASSD) of 0.72 mm, and a volume overlap error (VOE) of 11.91%. Furthermore, cross-dataset validation on the AMOS 2022 dataset obtains an average Dice of 85.09%, IoU of 76.66%, ASSD of 19.49 mm, and VOE of 23.34%, indicating strong generalization across different datasets. These results confirm the effectiveness and robustness of HANS-Net in providing anatomically consistent, accurate, and confident liver and tumor segmentation.

title: MR 2 SLAM: Multi-Robot Monocular Resilient SLAM for Ill-conditioned Problems
authors: Zidi Yang, Jiansheng Li, Guangyun Li, Huakai Zhao, Ancheng Wang
abstract: Monocular visual-inertial simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) estimates the 3D positions of landmarks through triangulation of inter-frame tracked features. However, due to limited parallax between frames and highly consistent camera motion, the triangulation process frequently becomes ill-conditioned. To address this, we propose MR2SLAM, a Multi-Robot Monocular Resilient SLAM for ill-conditioned problems. MR2SLAM leverages collective observations of feature points from multiple robots to perform joint triangulation, benefiting from diverse viewpoints, complex epipolar geometry, and improved robustness against ill-conditioning. Furthermore, to fully leverage multi-robot collaborative observations and mitigate the impact of visual data degradation in any single robot on the overall system, MR2SLAM resiliently adjusts the weights between map points generated through multi-robot collaboration and those from individual robots in back-end optimization. This is achieved by updating the information matrix using reprojection errors. We evaluate our method on a multi-vehicle dataset collected in underground environments. Results show that, compared to VINS-Mono, the proposed method reduces the average condition number by 92.56% and improves the average localization accuracy by 19.68%.

title: Monitoring Intelligent Connected Vehicles: Embedding Trust Levels in Status Within Zero-Trust Network Architecture
authors: Shenghui Guo, Darong Huang, Choon Ki Ahn, Yihong Zhou, Jiafeng Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of distributed state monitoring for intelligent connected vehicle (ICV) fleets based on embedded trust levels within a zero-trust network architecture (ZTNA) while considering the impact of unknown input disturbances. The ZTNA significantly enhances the overall security performance of the vehicle fleet. To implement the “never trust, always verify” principle, we first analyze the effects of zero-trust architecture on the communication relationships among intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs). Drawing inspiration from human trust dynamics, rules for establishing and reducing trust levels between vehicles are formulated. A variable-directed graph is employed to represent the communication topology of the entire vehicle fleet. Next, a distributed unknown input monitor structure is proposed using known information and verified global state monitoring results from neighboring vehicles with embedded trust levels. By utilizing selectable matrices to process local and global control inputs, any individual vehicle can monitor the state of the entire fleet. Finally, a simulation analysis of a fleet of six vehicle nodes demonstrates the correctness and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: FL in Motion: Accelerating FL via Mobility-Aware Vehicle Selection and Sparse Training
authors: Haoyu Tu, Wen Wu, Lin Chen, Liang Li, Xu Chen, Xuemin Shen
abstract: Although Federated Learning (FL) can enable advanced autonomous driving via leveraging massive distributed data in vehicular networks, vehicle mobility causes frequent connection interruptions, hindering the FL process. In this paper, we propose a novel <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M</u>obility-<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</u>ware <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">V</u>ehicular <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">FL</u> (MAVFL) scheme, which can accelerate the training process in dynamic vehicular networks via adaptive vehicle selection and sparse training. Specifically, the MAVFL dynamically selects participating vehicles based on their locations and training loss. By incorporating adaptive model sparsification, the proposed scheme dynamically proceeds with sparse masks during vehicle local training, thereby reducing communication overhead while preserving model accuracy. We conduct a rigorous convergence analysis to uncover how vehicle mobility and model sparsification affect convergence rate. Furthermore, we formulate an optimization problem to accelerate the training process, which jointly optimizes vehicle selection, sparsification ratio, and bandwidth allocation to minimize training delay. To solve the problem, we employ the Lyapunov optimization method to decouple the long-term problem into a series of instantaneous subproblems. Next, a generalized Benders decomposition method structures the original problem into a master subproblem for vehicle selection and a primal subproblem for bandwidth allocation and sparsification ratio selection. The optimal solutions are derived via alternating iterations between these problems. Extensive simulation results based on the SUMO simulator demonstrate that the MAVFL accelerates model convergence by up to 14% and reduces communication overhead by up to 26% while preserving model accuracy, as compared to the state-of-the-art benchmarks.

title: Few-shot Rotating Machinery Bearing Fault Diagnosis with Denoising Diffusion based Data Augmentation
authors: Xinyue Wang, Liqing Fang, Jinli Che, Ziqi Wang
abstract: Fault detection and diagnosis of bearings are crucial for maintaining the operational integrity of rotating machinery. However, the scarcity of fault samples, particularly for rare faults, leads to severe data imbalance, which consequently degrades model performance and increases false alarm rates. Although deep learning methods have improved diagnostic accuracy, models based on one-dimensional data often struggle to effectively capture the complex spatiotemporal correlation characteristics inherent in bearing faults. To address this challenge, this study proposes an innovative data augmentation framework that integrates a Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM) with Gramian Angular Field (GAF) transformation, and presents an intelligent fault diagnosis method for bearings under small-sample conditions. The proposed method first processes vibration signals acquired from a three-channel sensor using the Piecewise Aggregate Approximation (PAA) algorithm to generate RGB-formatted Gramian Angular Difference Field (GADF) images. The size of the resulting images is then reduced by employing bicubic interpolation-based downsampling. Subsequently, building upon these prepared samples, we introduce an improved U-Net architecture within the DDPM, designated the IGM-DDPM, which achieves the fusion of deep holistic and salient features to enhance the sample generation process. The quality of the generated samples is evaluated using the Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) as a metric. Finally, an improved fault diagnosis model based on EfficientNet-B0 integrated with Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) is proposed. By refining the number of input channels at each stage, this model mitigates overfitting and improves diagnostic effectiveness. Experimental results from multiple designed validation tests demonstrate that the proposed image enhancement method can effectively improve fault features within the images and maintain satisfactory diagnostic performance.

title: Robust Formation Tracking of ASVs With Nonconservative Collision Avoidance: A Control Barrier Function-Based Approach
authors: Guanghui Wen, Junjie Fu, Bowen Wang, Xudong Wang, Han Shen
abstract: This article addresses the robust formation tracking control problem for multiple underactuated autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs) subject to bounded unknown disturbances. A high-order control barrier function (HOCBF) based collision avoidance formation tracking framework is proposed which combines a nominal controller and the HOCBF induced collision avoidance conditions. First, a predefined-time observer based nominal controller is proposed for the multi-ASV system which achieves formation tracking under general directed communication graphs. Then, a novel HOCBF based collision avoidance method is proposed for ASVs modeled by elliptical shapes to reduce conservatism introduced by conventional circular occupancy area assumptions. Finally, local quadratic optimization problems are established for the ASVs such that the robust collision avoidance formation tracking is achieved with minimal deviation from the nominal trajectories. Extensive simulation and physical experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy.

title: Decoder-Based Anomaly Detection with Concentration Filtering for Distinguishing Wildfire Smoke from Clouds
authors: Sehun Kim, Chaebong Sohn, Kwangchul Son
abstract: Wildfires are natural disasters that cause extensive human casualties and economic losses worldwide. Rapid detection in the early stages is essential to minimize damage; however, conventional supervised learning-based object detection methods face limitations due to the difficulty of acquiring sufficient labeled data for rare wildfire events and their high implementation costs. This study proposes an unsupervised wildfire-detection framework that leverages the characteristics of fixed closed-circuit television (CCTV) environments. The core of the proposed method is a Learnable Concentration Filtering Module that quantifies the spatial distribution differences between wildfire smoke and atmospheric clouds. To extract robust feature representations, we employ ConvNeXt, a modernized convolutional architecture that integrates Vision Transformer design principles to achieve superior performance. Multi-scale features are extracted using a this backbone, and each feature map is divided into fixed 14 × 14 patches. Spatial correlations between patches are learned through local-window self-attention. From the decoder-based reconstruction error map, the concentration ratio defined as the ratio of local maximum to mean values are computed at multiple scales, and concentrated anomaly patterns are selectively extracted through learnable thresholds. Experimental results on four regions of the HPWREN dataset achieved an average area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) of 0.801, average precision (AP) of 0.689, and maximum F1-score (F1-max) of 0.769, demonstrating improved performance over other state-of-the-art anomaly detection models. The proposed method achieved a fast inference time of 10.53 ms, confirming its real-time processing capability. This study presents a practical approach for developing wildfire-detection systems that are robust to environmental variations and do not require labeled data.

title: Metamorphic Testing for Vision-Based Autonomous Driving With Road Traffic Risk Exposure Extrapolation
authors: Zhengmin Jiang, Shunran Zhang, Jia Liu, Huiyun Li, Yi Pan, Jianping Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Autonomous Driving Systems (ADS) are critical components of Intelligent Transportation Systems (ITS), where vehicle-level reliability has a direct bearing on road traffic safety. Evaluating ADS performance in complex environments remains challenging due to the absence of test oracles and the heavy reliance on deep learning. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel metamorphic testing framework tailored for vision-based ADS. First, causal inference is employed to extract key environmental factors from high-dimensional observational traffic data, thereby reducing the test space. Second, a multi-objective optimization algorithm integrating causal counterfactual reasoning is developed to quantify the challenges associated with specific combinations of causal factors, enabling cost-effective exploration of test conditions. Third, low-risk source images are systematically transformed into hazardous driving scenes through a fine-tuned diffusion model, allowing ADS evaluation to be guided by metamorphic relations (MRs). Empirical experiments show that the proposed method achieves a higher fault detection ratio than the strongest baseline in four out of five ADS models, with relative gains ranging from 18.1% to 88.9%. Data augmentation experiments further demonstrate that incorporating MR-violating test cases can reduce ADS prediction errors by up to 13.67%, with these benefits preserved in real-world road traffic datasets through domain adaptation. This study highlights a new pathway for validating the reliability of vision-based ADS driven by deep learning, thereby supporting the deployment of safer road transportation. The source code for our methods and baselines is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/SafeDL/AutoMetTest</uri>

title: A Comparative Analysis of Web Automation Testing Tools: Selenium Webdriver, Playwright, and Webdriverio Using an AHP-TOPSIS Approach
authors: Guruh Aryotejo, Hernan Sandi Laksono, Satriawan Rasyid Purnama, Eko Adi Sarwoko, Beta Noranita, Shan-Hsiang Shen
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: The proliferation of web automation testing tools presents a significant challenge for developers and QA engineers in selecting the most suitable solution. This study provides a systematic comparative analysis of three leading tools: Selenium WebDriver, Playwright, and WebDriverIO. The evaluation was conducted using two Single Sign-On (SSO) systems as case studies: one, a newly developed SSO system for Early Childhood Education (PAUD), and the other, an existing production-level SSO system at Diponegoro University (UNDIP). A hybrid multicriteria decision-making (MCDM) model, combining the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) for criteria weighting and the Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) for ranking, was employed. The tools were assessed based on two primary parameters: technical efficiency (script execution time, test stability, CPU utility, RAM usage) and ease of use (script creation time, programming language support, cross-browser support, cost). The results consistently ranked Selenium WebDriver as the most optimal tool (preference score: 1.0000), primarily due to its superior resource efficiency and high flexibility. Playwright followed (preference scores: 0.8317 & 0.6740), excelling in execution time, while WebDriverIO ranked third (preference score: 0.0000). This research offers a data-driven guide for selecting automation tools tailored to specific project needs.

title: Unshielded Magnetorelaxometry of Nanogram-Scale Magnetic Particles with an YIG-Based Gradientometer System
authors: Olesya Lutsenko, Denis Taurenis, Pavel Kapralov, Nikolay Koshev, Mikhail Zharkov, Nikolay Pyataev, Maxim Ostras, Igor Radchenko, Svetlana Evstigneeva, Gleb Sukhorukov
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This work presents a novel YIG-based gradientometer system specifically designed for high-performance magnetorelaxometry (MRX) applications. The two-channel impedance-based yttrium-iron garnet (IM-YIG) sensor achieves an exceptional magnetic field sensitivity of 10 pT/√Hz combined with ultrafast (less than 1 ms) dead time, enabling precise measurement of rapid magnetic particle relaxation dynamics. The gradiometric configuration provides effective common-mode interference rejection while maintaining a wide dynamic range essential for MRX studies. The developed system demonstrates several key advantages over traditional approaches: it operates at room temperature without requiring cryogenic infrastructure or complex optical components, significantly simplifying experimental setups while improving measurement stability, and works without magnetic shielded environment. Comprehensive testing with magnetic particle samples verified the system’s capability to reliably detect relaxation signals corresponding to iron masses as low as 50 ng. Furthermore, analysis of baseline stability suggests potential for even lower detection limits through optimized signal processing. The system’s robust performance and simplified architecture make it particularly suitable for deployment in resource-constrained environments where conventional SQUID or OPM systems would be impractical.

title: MLSMOTE for Multi-Label Text Classification in Toxic Comment
authors: Kevin Tan, Shanella Christina, Said Achmad, Derwin Suhartono
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Toxic comments such as hate speech, abusive language, and online bullying appear more and more frequently on digital platforms, threatening the safety of users and online communities. One of the main challenges in multi-label toxic comment classification is data imbalance, where some types of comments appear infrequently, making it difficult to be recognized by the model. This research aims to improve the classification performance by applying Multi-label Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (MLSMOTE) as an oversampling method to balance the label distribution. The dataset used comes from the Jigsaw Toxic Comment Classification Challenge, and the text features are converted into numerical data using TF-IDF. Three machine learning models were tested, namely OneVsRest Logistic Regression, OneVsRest Linear SVC, and MultiOutputClassifier with Random Forest. Evaluation was done using accuracy, precision, recall, and micro F1-score metrics. The results showed that MLSMOTE improved recall and micro F1-score values consistently across all models. The best performance, with a micro F1 score of 0.7474 and a recall of 0.7278, was achieved by the model Random Forest. This demonstrates that oversampling approaches, such as MLSMOTE, are highly effective in addressing data imbalance, enabling more accurate detection of various types of toxic comments. Therefore, this strategy supports the development of automated content moderation systems that are more accurate and fairer in identifying problematic comments.

title: Flexible MIMO for Future Wireless Communications: Which Flexibilities Are Possible?
authors: Zhe Wang, Jiayi Zhang, Bokai Xu, Wenhui Yi, Emil Björnson, Bo Ai
abstract: In conventional multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO), static array configurations struggle in dynamic environments, and further antenna scaling is bounded by cost, energy, and footprint. Emerging approaches, which can enable next-generation wireless communication networks with modest spectrum availability by leveraging flexibility and adaptability rather than sheer array growth, are therefore needed. In this paper, we present a taxonomy framework, referred to as flexible MIMO technology, that systematically categorizes a wide range of evolving MIMO technologies. The focus is on MIMO technologies with flexible physical configurations and integrated applications. We categorize twelve representative flexible MIMO technologies into three major classifications: flexible deployment characteristics-based, flexible geometry characteristics-based, and flexible real-time modifications-based. We then comprehensively overview their fundamental characteristics, potential, and challenges. In addition, we highlight three vital enablers for flexible MIMO technology, including efficient channel state information acquisition schemes, low-complexity beamforming design, and explainable artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled optimization, and discuss eight representative sub-techniques. Finally, two brief case studies—pre-optimized irregular array for high-speed railway network and cell-free movable antenna—are presented, showing how flexible MIMO can open new design possibilities and inspire future research directions for next-generation wireless networks.

title: Robust Stability of Boolean Networks With Multiple Disturbances: An Eigenvalue-Based Approach
authors: Yuanyuan Li, Hankang Ji, Jianquan Lu, Jungang Lou
publish: IEEE Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Magazine
abstract: Stability analysis is a key topic in the study of Boolean networks (BNs). This article proposes a novel eigenvalue-based method to study the robust stability of BNs with multiple disturbances. Unlike existing stability results, this article investigates robust stability from the perspective of eigenvalues rather than the transition matrix. To demonstrate the versatility of this new method in robust stability analysis, we introduce a stochastic BN (SBN) with both stochastic sequences and Markovian jump disturbances (MJDs), which can also be viewed as an extended SBN. Subsequently, we propose an algorithm to construct the largest invariant subsets (LISs) and give an eigenvalue-based method to determine the stability of SBNs. Finally, an example is used to verify the effectiveness of the results in this article.

title: A Method for Coal Flow Foreign Object Detection and Mineral Semantic Segmentation Based on the Lightweight Multitask Model PVDNet
authors: Hui Zheng, Wenming Guo, Changde Yang, Tingyu Fan
abstract: To address the separation of mineral semantic segmentation and foreign object detection in coal mine conveyor belt detection, and the inability of traditional single-task models to balance small target detection and complex boundary segmentation, this paper proposes a lightweight multi-task model, PVDNet, for simultaneous optimization of multi-category mineral segmentation and foreign object detection. Firstly, a coal mine semantic segmentation dataset (CsSS) comprising 6 mineral categories and 4 foreign object categories was constructed, and MobileSAM-assisted annotation and controllable synthesis were employed to mitigate sample scarcity and category imbalance. Secondly, based on PIDNet, an improved TinyViT backbone was introduced, along with a hierarchical perception multi-scale fusion framework and a dual-attention FusedBlock module, to enhance feature extraction and collaboration between semantic details. For gradient conflict in multi-task learning, a hierarchical gradient pruning strategy integrated with PCGrad was proposed to improve convergence speed and training stability; a differentiated multi-task loss function was also designed to balance optimization objectives. Experimental results show that PVDNet achieves 95.16% mIoU (0.93% higher than the current optimal model) in mineral segmentation, 89.49% mAP (outperforming similar models) in foreign object detection, with only 18.39M parameters and 43.06 FPS inference speed (higher than the fastest existing model). PVDNet outperforms mainstream multi-task models in accuracy and efficiency, showing good industrial deployment potential.

title: Simplifying Automated Testing: A Codeless, Interaction-Recording Script Builder Approach to Accelerate Automated Testing Method
authors: Dzikri Mutawakkil Al Hamdika, Adam Shidqul Aziz, Desy Intan Permatasari, Umi Sa'adah, Nailus Nailus Nailussa'ada, Maulidan Bagus Afridian Rasyid, Ahmad Jarir At Thobari
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: The growing number of students at the Electronic Engineering Polytechnic Institute of Surabaya (EEPIS), alongside the implementation of Product-Based Learning (PdBL), has intensified the demand for reliable and efficient software testing solutions. Although Appium is a widely adopted framework for automated testing, the manual creation of test scripts remains a considerable barrier, particularly for less experienced developers. This research presents the design and development of an automated testing script generator that employs a record-and-playback mechanism to streamline the test creation process. The system consists of two main modules: an interaction recorder embedded within the application to capture user behaviors, and a test runner that automatically translates these interactions into executable Appium scripts. A key innovation lies in leveraging native Flutter widget keys within the embedded recorder, enabling the generation of more stable and maintainable test scripts compared to conventional locator-based approaches. Experimental results indicate that the proposed platform reduces script development time by up to 97.99 % and accelerates regression testing by 14.63 %. Achieving a test execution success rate of 75 %, the system demonstrates its potential to increase developer productivity, minimize human error, and lower the entry barrier for automated testing adoption.

title: SLChain: A Stochastic Lightweight Blockchain with Selfish Mining Attack Mitigation
authors: Sheng-Wei Wang, Show-Shiow Tzeng, Li-Chun Wang
abstract: High computational power consumption is a significant problem in a Proof-of-Work blockchain. Restricting the total mining power or the number of miners is a possible solution to save computational power consumption. However, reducing the mining power or the number of miners raises concerns about fairness and security. In this paper, we propose a stochastic lightweight blockchain called SLChain in which a random subset of miners is selected to mine the next block. In the proposed SLChain, the power consumption is significantly reduced while maintaining fairness among miners, robustness to multiple types of attacks, and block time consistency. Furthermore, the proposed SLChain can mitigate selfish mining attacks. We derive an analytical model to calculate the rewards earned by selfish miners. Simulations are conducted to study the accuracy of the proposed analytical model. From the numerical results, we found that the profitable threshold of selfish mining attacks increases from 25% to 29.29% in the proposed SLChain. In summary, the proposed stochastic lightweight blockchain can simultaneously reduce computational power consumption, maintain fairness and security levels, ensure block time consistency, and mitigate selfish mining attacks simultaneously.

title: Crisis-Aware Dual-Path Modeling for Depression Severity Assessment on Facial Signals Imbalanced Clinical Data
authors: Stefanus Benhard, Yulyani Arifin
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Depression remains a critical global health issue, causing disability and high rates of suicide wordwide. World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that depression affects around 3.8% of the population, causing over 700,000 suicides each year. While early detection is a focus of the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) Goal 3, current methods that rely on self-reported questionnaires, may be biased and often miss severe cases, especially in clinical data with strong class imbalance which is natural in real-world distribution. This study introduces a crisis-aware dual-head deep learning framework for estimating depression severity from facial signals, using anchor-based temporal segmentation and clincialpriority loss function to improve detection of high-severity subjects without additional synthetic class balancing. This study has been evaluated on DAIC-WOZ dataset with LOSO-CV validation. The CNN1D model on this framework achieves MAE 4.56 and MSE 34.31, outperforming previous approaches and overcoming regression over the mean statistic challenges because the results is dispersed. These results suggest the proposed method offers a more reliable and practical tool for early depression screening in clinical settings.

title: Dual DC Bus Rectifier with Embedded Power Decoupling for Airborne Pulsed Load Application
authors: Jianxin Zhu, Yubin Duan, Hongfei Wu, Fan Yang, Guanhong Chen, Yan Xing
abstract: As a special type of load, the radar transmitter poses a significant challenge to the safe and stable operation of the airborne power system due to its pulsating characteristics. A dual DC bus rectifier structure has been proposed to achieve pulse current suppression and power quality improvement. A comprehensive analysis of the circuit configuration of the dual DC bus rectifier is presented, based on the traditional two-level converter. Operation principle and control scheme of the dual DC bus rectifier are analyzed in detail, and a hybrid SVPWM strategy is proposed to achieve power regulation between the two DC buses. A prototype is built and tested to verify the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed dual DC bus rectifier and its control method.
