title: Anatomically-informed Multi-Resonant RF Sensor for Personalized Fingertip-Based Glucose Monitoring
authors: Marwa Omer Mohammed Omer, Mohamed Ishag Hassan Gama, Saminu Abdullahi, Rayan Merghani Ahmed Mahjoub, Jingzhen Li, Zedong Nie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Non-invasive glucose monitoring stands as a key pursuit in digital health, aiming to reduce the burden of frequent blood sampling for diabetic individuals. Radio frequency (RF) sensors emerge as promising solutions due to their non-contact nature and sensitivity to dielectric changes. However, their accuracy remains constrained by inconsistent tissue interaction resulting from subject-to-subject variability in skin thickness. In this study, we developed a stepped-line interdigital capacitor (SLIDC)-based RF sensor for anatomically-informed, multi-resonant glucose monitoring at the fingertip. The SLIDC is incorporated with a substrate-integrated waveguide (SIW) to ensure compactness for fingertip application, and a Defected Ground Structure (DGS) for enhanced operational bandwidth. The sensor was validated through in-vitro and in-vivo experiments. For in-vitro testing, 3D-structured PET-based fingertip-mimicking microfluidic layers with varying thicknesses (0.3–0.6 mm) were used, while in-vivo testing was conducted using human volunteers. Verification results showed that each resonance frequency was associated with a specific thickness, demonstrating the ability of the sensor to identify individualized optimal sensing frequencies. Strong mean correlations were seen with glucose concentration, recording |R| up to 0.98, and |R| up to 0.9 for in-vitro and in-vivo tests respectively. These findings confirm the system’s potential for tissue-thickness-informed, subject-specific glucose monitoring, supporting the future development of fingertip-deployable RF biosensors for digital health applications.

title: Amalgamated CHIRP and OFDM for ISAC
authors: Pankaj Kumar, Mohammed El-Hajjar, Ibrahim A. Hemadeh, Yasser Mestrah, Suraj Srivastava, Aditya K. Jagannatham, Lajos Hanzo
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) requires the development of a waveform capable of efficiently supporting both communication and sensing functionalities. This paper proposes a novel waveform that combines the benefits of both the orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) and the Chirp waveforms to improve both the communication and sensing performance within an ISAC framework. Hence, a new architecture is proposed that utilizes the conventional communication framework while leveraging the parameters sensed at the receiver (Rx) for enhancing the communication performance. We demonstrate that the affine addition of OFDM and chirp signals results in a near constant-envelope OFDM waveform, which effectively reduces the peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR), a key limitation of traditional OFDM systems. Using the OFDM framework for sensing in the conventional fashion requires the allocation of some resources for sensing, which in turn reduces communication performance. As a remedy, the proposed affine amalgam facilitates sensing through the chirp waveform without consuming communication resources, thereby preserving communication efficiency. Furthermore, a novel technique of integrating the chirp signal into the OFDM framework at the slot-level is proposed to enhance the accuracy of range estimation. The results show that the OFDM signal incorporated with chirp has better autocorrelation properties, improved root mean square error (RMSE) of range and velocity, and lower PAPR. Finally, we characterize the trade-off between communications and sensing performance.

title: Efficient and Unbounded Public-key Encryption with Keyword Search Based on Arithmetic Span Programs in Cloud Storage
authors: Hu Xiong, Xiyue Zhang, Jun Feng, Kehan Gao, Keshav Sood
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Public-key Encryption with Keyword Search (PEKS) enables users to search encrypted data stored on an untrusted server without revealing any sensitive information. However, existing PEKS schemes are typically inefficient and lack the flexibility to support complex search policies. To address this, a novel PEKS scheme based on Arithmetic Span Programs (PEKS-ASP) is proposed in this paper. This is the first scheme to enable flexible and efficient search policies by using directed acyclic graphs. This approach enhances the efficiency of complex search queries that implement AND, OR, and NOT gates, enabling a more efficient representation of complicated search policies without redundancy in keyword usage. And our proposed PEKS-ASP scheme guarantees constant-size public parameters regardless of the number of keywords. Additionally, the proposed scheme achieves adaptive security under the matrix decisional Diffie-Hellman (MDDH) assumption, employing dual system encryption techniques. Both theoretical analysis and experimental results demonstrate that PEKS-ASP significantly improves efficiency and practicality, making it well-suited for practical applications in various cloud environments.

title: NearSense: Exploring NearLink for New-Generation Wireless Sensing
authors: Zijun Han, Xuanzhi Wang, Yang Li, Dan Wu, Hongliu Yang, Wanru Ning, Zhiyun Yao, Wenwei Li, Xingqing Cheng, Zixiang Ma, Daqing Zhang
abstract: Recent years have witnessed considerable efforts in repurposing ubiquitous wireless communication signals for non-contact sensing. <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\bf{NearLink}$</tex-math></inline-formula> is a new-generation short-range wireless communication protocol, which is designed to address the high-quality network connectivity requirements of low power, low latency and high reliability. Given these notable advantages, NearLink has great potential for widespread application in various Internet of Things (IoT) areas. However, NearLink-based wireless sensing has not yet been explored. To bridge this gap, this work explores for the first time the sensing potential and opportunities of NearLink. Specifically, we systematically investigate the sensing capability of NearLink through answering two key questions: (1) How can NearLink's communication-oriented signals be adapted for sensing tasks? (2) How can sensing performance be enhanced under multipath interference and low-power constraints? We prototype the NearLink sensing system-NearSense, and take the respiration detection as a case study to demonstrate its effectiveness. Extensive experiments demonstrate that NearSense can achieve an average detection rate of 98% and a false alarm rate below 1.5% in case of various real-life challenging interference. We believe this work opens up new directions for the new-generation wireless sensing towards high-quality network connections.

title: Autonomous Power Ripple Suppression Scheme for Grid-Connected Multiport Converters Under Unbalanced Grid Conditions
authors: Kai Liao, Dehong Zhou, Jianxiao Zou, Xin Liu
abstract: The active power decoupling technique is a promising solution for grid-connected converters under unbalanced grid conditions due to its advanced merits in simultaneously achieving negative-sequence current elimination and active power ripple suppression. However, an extra power decoupling circuit, along with a complex power ripple tracking controller, should be designed for these purposes. Given this, this article proposes an autonomous power ripple suppression scheme that achieves both active power ripple suppression and negative-sequence current elimination based on a grid-connected multiport converter. In the proposed scheme, negative-sequence current elimination is implemented at the ac port, and the dc-port power is controlled to be constant to suppress active power ripples. Thus, the differential power ripples are autonomously buffered by the ripple port. Besides, the multiport converter is decomposed into an upper-port converter and a lower-port converter to ease the modulation design under time-varying dc-link voltages. With the proposed scheme, balanced three-phase grid currents and ripple-free dc output voltage are simultaneously obtained under unbalanced grid conditions without extra power ripple controllers. Experimental results are presented to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme.

title: Time-series Data-driven Three Dimensional Shape Control of Deformable Linear Objects using a Dual-arm Robot with Dynamic Model Updating
authors: Jiyoung Choi, Micheale Haileslassie Gebrezgiher, Donggun Lee, Ayoung Hong
abstract: Deformable objects (DOs) are prevalent in everyday environments and represent important targets for robotic manipulation. However, their high degrees of freedom and complex nonlinear deformations make them more challenging to model and control than rigid objects when relying on traditional analytical approaches. To address this, we propose a data-driven method to model the dynamics of deformable objects. Our method utilizes time-series data to predict future states without relying on complex dynamics. We employ model predictive control (MPC) for robot manipulation and improve its performance through online updates of the data-driven model. To handle cables with varying configurations, interpolation is applied to align model input structures. In this study, we focus on manipulating deformable linear objects (DLOs) with different mechanical properties and configurations using a dual-arm robotic system, both in simulation and in real-world environments.

title: GeoTexDensifier: Geometry-Texture-Aware Densification for High-Quality Photorealistic 3D Gaussian Splatting_supp1-3644697.mp4
authors: Guofeng Zhang
abstract: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has recently attracted wide attentions in various areas such as 3D navigation, Virtual Reality (VR) and 3D simulation, due to its photorealistic and efficient rendering performance. High-quality reconstrution of 3DGS relies on sufficient splats and a reasonable distribution of these splats to fit real geometric surface and texture details, which turns out to be a challenging problem. We present GeoTexDensifier, a novel geometry-texture-aware densification strategy to reconstruct high-quality Gaussian splats which better comply with the geometric structure and texture richness of the scene. Specifically, our GeoTexDensifier framework carries out an auxiliary texture-aware densification method to produce a denser distribution of splats in fully textured areas, while keeping sparsity in low-texture regions to maintain the quality of Gaussian point cloud. Meanwhile, a geometry-aware splitting strategy takes depth and normal priors to guide the splitting sampling and filter out the noisy splats whose initial positions are far from the actual geometric surfaces they aim to fit, under a Validation of Depth Ratio Change checking. With the help of relative monocular depth prior, such geometry-aware validation can effectively reduce the influence of scattered Gaussians to the final rendering quality, especially in regions with weak textures or without sufficient training views. The texture-aware densification and geometry-aware splitting strategies are fully combined to obtain a set of high-quality Gaussian splats. We experiment our GeoTexDensifier framework on various datasets and compare our Novel View Synthesis results to other state-of-the-art 3DGS approaches, with detailed quantitative and qualitative evaluations to demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in producing more photorealistic 3DGS models.

title: Deep Learning for Marine Fish Classification via CNN-Based Computer Vision
authors: Abdul Haris Rangkuti, Shafa Naura Livka Naycilla, Katrin Manalu, Nadila Zindi Aulia Putri
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Informatics and Computational Sciences (ICICoS)
abstract: Marine fish recognition and classification are crucial for marine ecosystem monitoring, fisheries management, and biodiversity conservation. However, this process faces complex technical, environmental, and data challenges. The problem of marine fish recognition and classification is complex and multidimensional, encompassing biological challenges such as species similarity, data quality, feature extraction, and computational limitations. Effective solutions require a multidisciplinary approach, the integration of advanced technologies, and collaboration between marine biologists and computer scientists. Recent innovations in deep learning, transfer learning, and multimodal data integration continue to drive progress in the recognition of a wide variety of marine fish species. This study was conducted to recognize nine classes of marine fish species using deep learning models. Evaluations showed that the CNN method was highly effective, with most models achieving accuracy above 90%. The DenseNet121 model performed best with 93% accuracy, 94% precision, 93% recall, and 93% F1 score, followed by the ResNet50V2, InceptionV3, and MobileNetV2 models with average accuracy above 80%. These evaluations inform the great potential of the CNN Model approach in supporting the automation of recognizing marine fish species for the conservation and efficient utilization of marine resources.

title: Adaptive Gridless Covariance-Matching DOA Estimation for Coprime Array under Impulsive Noise
authors: Jing Song, Lin Cao, Zongmin Zhao, Kehu Yang, Dongfeng Wang, Chong Fu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In symmetric α-stable (SαS)-distributed impulsive noise, classical direction of arrival (DOA) estimators degrade markedly due to heavy-tailed statistics. To address this, we propose an adaptive, gridless DOA method for coprime arrays. First, we design a condition-selection phased fractional lower-order moment scheme that determines the fractional order by minimizing the condition number, thereby accommodating varying noise intensities without prior knowledge of the characteristic index α. Then, leveraging the virtual uniform linear array formed by the coprime difference coarray, we establish a covariance-matching gridless sparse reconstruction framework to estimate DOAs, eliminating angular grid mismatch and internalizing regularization selection within a constrained optimization, thus avoiding manual tuning. Numerical simulations indicate that, across a broad range of generalized signal-to-noise ratios, snapshot counts, and noise intensities, the proposed method delivers overall gains in estimation accuracy and resolution over existing approaches. Real-world validation using a millimeter-wave radar sensor further verifies its detection performance and practical utility.

title: Cybertwin-Enhanced Distributed Authentication with Lightweight Cryptography for Secure Internet of Vehicles
authors: Chang Liu, Hongmin Wei, Zheng Xue, Jiawen Kang, Xiaobin Xu, Guojun Han
abstract: The rapid development of the Internet of Vehicles (IoV) has increased the demand for robust authentication protocols capable of handling vehicle-node dynamics and resisting attacks. Traditional centralized methods, which suffer from latency and single-point failure issues, cannot meet IoV's real-time requirements. Although distributed authentication improves scalability and responsiveness, existing approaches still confront challenges regarding stability and reliability in dense vehicular networks due to static trust mechanisms and inefficient cryptographic operations. To address these challenges, we propose a Cybertwin-Enabled Distributed Authentication (CEDA) scheme that leverages lightweight cryptography and Cybertwin technology to reconstruct the authentication framework featuring dynamic trust distribution and real-time behavioral analytics. Specifically, CEDA establishes virtual digital twins of vehicles to enable real-time behavior tracking and dynamic simulation, thus enabling data-driven selection of vehicle agents based on real-time behavioral similarity. This mechanism reduces dependence on centralized trusted authorities by distributing trust across a network of dynamically selected agents, thereby enhancing fault tolerance and resilience against attacks. Furthermore, CEDA integrates an Edwards-curve-based digital signature algorithm to streamline cryptographic computations, significantly reducing authentication latency while strengthening security. A dynamic agent selection mechanism based on real-time vehicle behavior similarity further ensures efficient authentication in high-density vehicular environments. Comprehensive security analysis confirms the robustness of CEDA against a wide range of potential attacks, thus safeguarding the integrity of the IoV ecosystem. Simulation results demonstrate significant improvements in authentication efficiency and system scalability, particularly in scenarios involving frequent inter-regional vehicle authentications.

title: Multi-UAV Deployment and Resource Allocation: A federated deep reinforcement learning approach
authors: Yanan Zhu, Yueyu Ma, Xinxin Liu, He Wang, Wenwu Yu
publish: IEEE Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Magazine
abstract: As various communication methods evolve, the demand for communication services has surged. Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), due to their flexibility and low cost, have emerged as ideal platforms for providing convenient communication services. However, traditional centralized algorithms consume significant resources under limited communication capacity, while distributed algorithms often struggle to achieve effective collaboration. To address this challenge, this study proposes a multiagent federated reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm aimed at optimizing the deployment and resource allocation of multi-UAV to enhance network utility. The approach employs personalized proximal federated learning, allowing each agent to learn and train independently based on local observations, while periodically uploading model parameters to a central server. The central server maintains a global model and returns updated parameters with proximal terms, thereby improving cooperation among agents while reducing communication overhead. Additionally, the algorithm incorporates a reward network competition mechanism locally to provide effective target values for model training. To thoroughly validate the proposed algorithm’s effectiveness, a multi-UAV environment is constructed that comprehensively accounts for signal interference and transmission loss. Simulation results demonstrate that, across various complex environments, this algorithm outperforms traditional methods in terms of network utility.
